Title: The Dating Game Category: Gilmore Girls » Rory/Logan Disclaimer: The characters aren't mine. They belong to ASP and Co. No copyright infringement intended. Summary: Future-fic. When things begin to slip away, what to you do? You return to the beginning and start anew. Chapter Sixteen: 'Til Death Do Us Part "You went to my father?" This time it came out as a question, one that he needed her to answer. "Yes." As Logan pushed out of his chair, Rory immediately jumped to the defensive. "Logan, I'm sorry." He made a move to stamp toward her, but quickly decided against it, instead turning around to face the wall to haphazardly run his fingers through his hair. "Sorry? Rory how could you do that? You know how I felt... how I feel about him!" "I had no other choice!" "You always had a choice. You could've talked to me!" "Yeah, like that always went over well!" "You should've tried harder!" "You are a self-righteous bastard, you know that, right? Here you are putting all the blame on my shoulders when this is all YOUR fault." "It's takes two, Rory," he bit back in defense. She sighed in resignation. He was right, after all. She had put up as much fight to salvage their marriage as he did. "I'll admit that maybe I could've tried a bit harder to reach you, to get you to see me, but what would've been the point? Just like what is the point of us talking? All we do is argue and transfer the blame from one to the other." He grew silent for a few moments, breaking the silence only to ask, "How often?" "How often, what?" Logan walked toward her until he was standing in front of her. "How often do you see him? Talk to him?" She didn't like him being so close to her and she definitely did not like the way he was looking at her. He was trying to break her in half with his wayward stare and it was causing her knees to buckle... "I talk to him about twice a week. Sometimes more often than that. We meet for lunch a couple of times a month, too." The latter came out as a breathy confession, one that she hadn't intended on confessing at all, but flew out of her mouth unwillingly. "Are you sleeping with him, Rory?" Rory wasn't even sure what had compelled her to slap him. She just heard the smack the moment her hand contacted with his cheek and even his wild eyes did not have her cowering away or regretting her action. "I cannot believe that you just had the fucking balls to ask me that." Logan flexed his jaw. "Nice one. I certainly didn't expect that." "I want you to leave," she said, stalking to the door, throwing it open. She held it open, waiting for him to take the hint. After a few moments, Logan moved toward the open door, stopping in front of her to say, "This isn't over." "I believe it is," she said, slamming the door behind him, before collapsing against it. It was only after she had slid to the floor that she let her defenses down and welcomed the flood of tears. His life was a fucking mess, Logan mused as he reentered his house the following morning. He had thought going to visit her in Boston would have him returning with a positive attitude. He had hoped that they'd get all of their problems worked out, but that all fell short when she'd confessed of her business dealings with his father. HIS FATHER! Of all people for her to go to why did he have to be his father? Why didn't she go to Richard and Emily? Christopher, even? Why did it have to be the bane of his very existence? Logan peeled off his jacket as he touched his finger to the answering machine. He rolled his eyes through the messages from Stephanie, damning him to hell for the way he had been treating for Rory. He sighed exasperatedly through the one from Colin blasting him for showing up in Boston after she had made it crystal clear that she was going away to clear her head. And then the last one had him freezing midstep in the kitchen. "Logan...," came his sister's cracked voice. She sounded broken, exhausted and most like she had been crying. "Logan, please tell me you're home. GOD! Where are you? I've been trying to call you since yesterday. Why do you turn your damn phone off at the most inopportune times? When you get this get to Mount Sinai. There's been an accident. Dad's in the hospital. You need to be here. Logan, please, please be here." He felt his heart fall into his stomach. Despite his utter disregard for his father, Logan grabbed his keys and hurried out the door. A half-hour later he found himself at the hospital, breezing into the waiting room where his sister sat, sobbing in her husband's arms. She was at his side in a second, throwing her arms around his neck. "What happened?" he asked Josh, knowing that he wouldn't be able to understand Honor through her blubbering. "His jet malfunctioned on the runaway as it was readying for takeoff. They're thinking it was an electrical problem right now. It caught fire and your father is the only one that got out alive." "How is he?" "He's in critical condition right now, Logan. They won't let anyone in." "And where's Mom?" Honor leaned back, spatting out, "She's in Spain." "Spain?" "SPAIN!" Honor shouted before falling into his arms, her body convulsing with fresh sobs. It was going to be a long day, Logan sighed as he held his sister close to his chest. Rory was making her through the airport terminal when she heard her phone ringing from her purse. Groaning, she stopped to reach into her purse to grab the offending the device. "Gilmore," she spat out. "Where are you?" came Stephen's hasty voice. "Stephen?" "Yeah. Where are you?" "At JFK. I'm on my way to baggage claim to grab my bags," she said, resuming her walk. "What's up?" "I... uh... I don't know how to tell you this... you haven't heard the news?" Rory stopped dead in her tracks. "No. Why? What's happened?" "Mitchum Huntzberger is in the hospital, Rory." "What?" she rasped, her purse slipping from her grasp. "It's been all over the news," Stephen continued as she bent to recover her purse and the contents that had fallen from it. "What... what happened?" "I'm not really sure. The networks are all pretty vague on the details. I only know that it was an airplane accident." "I told him that that stupid little jet was going to be the death of him! I told him that!" she spat out angrily. "I didn't know if you knew and I just... I thought you should know since you and Mitchum are so close and I just... I thought maybe you'd want to be there for Logan." Logan! God! She wondered if he even knew... if he even cared. She didn't have time to debate that now. She had to get to the hospital. Rory quickly hung up with Stephen then made her way to baggage before she hailed a taxi and made her way to Mount Sinai. Logan was sitting at Mitchum's beside when she walked into the room. He looked so concerned, dejected... tired. Her heart went out to him. She stood there for a few moments silently watching him. His head was resting on the bed, grasping his father's lifeless hand in his own. When her feet finally moved toward him, she came to stand beside him, touching his shoulder to gently wake him. When his dark eyes landed on hers, they softened. He bolted out of his chair to envelop her in his arms. "I'm so glad you're here," he breathed into her hair. "I didn't know if you wanted me here or...," she trailed off, taking another sidelong glance at Mitchum's still form. "You're family. You have a right to be here," he said coolly before dropping himself back into his chair. "How is he?" she asked him. "How does he look?" Logan snapped at her. She didn't say anything further after that. They stayed for a long time listening to the music from the monitors, watching Mitchum's lifeless body going through the motions. It was as she made her way to leave that Logan spoke to her again. "Did you come for me... or for him?" At first she didn't know what to say. She knew that there was a right answer and a wrong answer and she didn't want to make him hurt anymore than he already was, but she owed him her honesty. It was the least she could do considering their enlightening conversation in Boston just days before. "I came because I was concerned." "Right." "Logan, I'm..." "Rory, it's fine. If you don't mind, I'd like to be alone with my father." As the days passed, the tension between she and Logan worsened the longer that Mitchum lay immobile. She tried her best to make him comfortable. She brought him coffee, food, his mail, hell even his work and nothing changed his attitude. He was closed off from her and she had no one to blame but herself. Perhaps her gravest mistake was trying to get him to leave his father's beside. He had chewed her head off, forcing her to scurrying out of the room in tears. Honor had found her in the bathroom, ready to console her, but Rory refused to let her. She was getting everything she deserved. She had stomped out of the bathroom that day and not returned until the next day, keeping her interaction with Logan very limited since then. Stephen had dropped by Friday afternoon, presenting her with Starbucks coffee and she had promised to build a statue in his honor. "How're you holding up?" he asked, wrapping a comforting arm around her shoulders. "Fine." Stephen eyed her skeptically. "No really?" Her deep sigh rocked her whole body. "I just wish he'd let me help him, but he won't. He's short with me and I just... I hate it." "And you think you deserve it?" "I don't think I do. I know I do, Stephen. I know that this is all my fault but it still doesn't make it hurt any less." "Just give him time, Rory. I'm sure he'll come around once his father is out of the woods." "I just hope you're right," she said, resting her head on his shoulder. "I'm glad you came." "Me too," he said, entwining their fingers together. It was as Logan made his way out of his father's room did he witness the intimate moment between the two friends. For once Mitchum's room was vacant. Rory moved to his bedside, falling into the chair beside his bed. "Oh, Mitchum, this has all gotten so out of hand," she said, taking his hand in hers. "I finally came clean to Logan about you saving the paper. Of course he was furious. We both expected it which was why we agreed that I not tell him. I'm sure he views it as some form of adultery. I'm sure he'll have no reservations to divorce me now and will I be able to blame him? Not at all." Taking his hand into both of hers, Rory brought it to her forehead, continuing along with her monologue. "I don't know what else to do, Mitchum. Keeping this from him has been eating me alive and I just... I couldn't do it anymore. If these past few days have taught me anything seeing you lying here like this it's that life is short. I can't go on pushing him away... but I just can't help but think I've lost him for good." "You... haven't," came the strained whisper from just above her head. Rory's head shot up, staring into his deep, penetrating eyes. "Mitchum?" "Hey there, Rory," he said, a cough erupting from his throat. "Do you need some water?" He nodded. Rory quickly filled a glass, lifting to his lips. "Not too fast," she coaxed. When he'd had enough, he pushed her hands gently away. "Do you want me to get Logan and Honor?" He shook his head. "No. Just you." She moved to sit beside him on the bed, taking his hand in hers once again. Logan made his way toward his father's room, stopping short when he spotted Lorelai down the hallway talking to the doctor. Rage seized him, but instead of taking it out on his mother-in-law he decided to take it off on her counterpart. He barged into his father's room ready to ream Rory for allowing her mother to talk to his father's doctor, stopping in his tracks when he saw his father sitting up in bed wide-awake, Rory at his side, her hand nestled with his. "Logan, look who's awake!" she said cheerfully. He stood frozen in the doorway, staring at the scene before him. "Hello Logan," came his father's gruff reply. "You lied to me," spat out angrily. "What?" Rory and Mitchum barked out in unison. He gestured to their joined hands. "You're having an affair." Mitchum let go of Rory's hand the exact same moment she let go of his. "Logan this is not what you think," Mitchum admonished. He hadn't spoken to his son and years and the last thing he wanted to do was argue with Logan while he was still recovering. "Then, what is it? It's no surprise mom tramped off to Spain without her cell and no means of contact. She found out about your latest fling!" Rory hopped from the bed. "Logan, your father and I are NOT sleeping together!" "Of course you are. Why else would my father agree to help you with your newspaper? It's not his M.O. Rory. He does NOTHING without getting something in return." Logan glared at his father. "What are you getting in return, Dad?" Mitchum started to respond but Rory cut him off. "No Mitchum. You don't have to say anything. I want you out of here, Logan!" Rory shouted. "What? He's MY father. I'm not leaving." "He just came out of a coma. He just survived a terrific ordeal and the last thing he needs is you coming in here and throwing accusations at him." He leveled her with a stern gaze, but she didn't deter. "You can look at me like that all you want, I don't care. If you don't believe that my relationship with your father is anything but platonic, fine, suit yourself. But I won't let you make me feel uncomfortable here. He wants me here. Now go." Logan left the room in a huff, slamming the door in his wake. She turned her head back to Mitchum as he said, "Thank you for doing that but you didn't have to. I can handle him." "No, he's my problem. I'll handle him."

Title: How Quickly Things Change Fandom: Gilmore Girls Rating: R Spoilers: None Disclaimer: I claim ownership to nothing. Summary: Post-Let Me Hear Your Balalaikas Ringing Out. Logan breaks up with Rory, leaving Colin to pick her up after her fall. Chapter Four: More Than Friends She stood up as he made his way down the sidewalk, picking up his speed as his eyes landed on her. "I'm sorry... I was a little rattled and I needed someone to talk to and the only person I wanted to talk to was you," she spat out, as he slowed to a stop in front of her. He smiled at her, glad that she was the one that he turned to. It made him feel useful. "It's okay. I'm glad you called." Grabbing her arm, he made her sit back down as he fell down beside her. "You didn't say much on the phone...," he began. "It was Logan," she blurted out quickly. It would have to be, he thought wryly. He pushed that thought aside as he asked, "So, what happened?" She shook her head, unable to voice the words aloud to him. She wasn't upset. She was embarassed. Seeing Logan had put into perspective what she and Colin had been doing. She knew that they weren't doing anything wrong. She and Logan were broken up and she and Colin were... What were they? Friends? More than friends? Were they on the cusp of dating? She wasn't sure. And she wanted to be sure. She needed to be sure. "He showed up the Gazette," she said simply. "To see you?" "God, no. He was there on business for his father." "He was doing Mitchum's leg work," Colin repeated. That wasn't a surprise. Mitchum usually goaded Logan into doing his work as a feeble attempt to get Logan interested in the family business. "Go on." "We... had words." "What'd he say?" "Him? He didn't say much. He started to apologize for dumping me, but I told him that I didn't want his apologies." She turned her eyes to meet Colin's. "And I don't. I don't need them." "This isn't your fault. Logan made the decision to end your relationship." "I know," she said with a smile. "This isn't about that. I'm not that broken up about it." "You're not?" She shook her head. "I saw him today for the first time since that night we broke up and I thought I'd feel... I don't know, something, anything... but I didn't. I did feel embarassed, though." "Embarassed? Why?" "Because of us. Because we've been spending all this time together and no one knows. Because he doesn't know." Colin shifted uncomforably on the bench. This conversation was taking an awkward turn. He wasn't sure where it was leading and he wasn't sure if he wanted to know where it's destination would take them. But he felt compelled to keep the conversation going. "We're not doing anything wrong here, Rory. We're friends, right? We're hanging out. We should haven't to hide it or make excuses for it." "But we have been, Colin. Hiding it, I mean." He stared at her blankly, not saying anything. "Why?" "Why, what? Why have we been hiding it?" "Yeah." He cleared his throat. "Uh, I, uh... I don't know." "You don't? Or you don't want to tell me?" she asked, hopeful. The more time she spent with Colin, the more she wanted to spend time with Colin. He was easy to talk to. He was fun. In a way he reminded her of Dean, but he also reminded her of Logan, as well. But Colin was different from all of her ex-boyfriends in his own right. Hearing the lift in her voice gave him the courage to put his feelings into words. He wasn't sure if she felt the same way that he did, but he would never know if he wasn't honest with her first. "I never intended to tell you this... I figured we could just continue being friends and it would all...," he trailed off, his eyes meeting hers for a brief second before he dropped them to stare at his shoes. "Well, anyway things are different and I can't continue spending time with you without you knowing." He licked his lips, then began his semi-confession. "I've liked you for awhile, but you were with Logan so knew I didn't have a chance. Being your friend has been enough, but it's not anymore. I can't just sit by and be your friend anymore. I know that I probably don't have a chance in hell, but I...," his words quickly fell away when she crossed the space lingering between them, pressing her lips to his. A few sweeps of her lips across his and then it was over. He sat, shocked, and a little bit shaky, when she pulled back. At first he wondered if his overactive imagination had conjured up the kiss from the deep recesses of his mind, but when he leaned toward her and she did it again, he knew that he wasn't hallucinating. "Wait, wait," he said, pushing her away. "What are we doing?" "We were kissing until you started talking." "I mean in the universal sense, Rory. What does this all mean?" She smiled as she played with the lapels on his jacket. "What do you want it to mean?" "I want it to mean... I guess I just don't want to be your rebound guy." Grabbing his hand, Rory pulled him to his feet, leading him in the direction of her car. "Where are we going?" "I want to take you somewhere." A half-hour later, they were driving. Well, Rory was driving. Colin sat in the passenger side seat, staring out the window, wondering where the hell she was taking him. "Where are we going?" he asked again for the umpteenth time since they'd left city. "Would you just sit back and relax? Geez." Colin did not deter. "I don't like not knowing the destination before we get there." "The fact that you just said that you detest the element of surprise subtracts from your coolness factor," Rory said glancing at him. "My best friend Lane will not like you. And neither will Lorelai." "Huh? And WHAT?" Rory couldn't help but laugh. She was glad to have erupted his control. She smiled as she entered Stars Hollow. "You need to just chill." "Hey, I've been here before," Colin said, taking in the surroundings as they swept into the tiny town. "It's my hometown, moron." "Where are we going?" He asked again. Rory pulled to a stop beside the curb outside Luke's Diner. "Out! Out! Out!" she said, unbuckling her seatbelt. She pushed open her door as Colin stumbled out from the other side, asking, "What are we doing here?" "I was hungry for a hamburger and Luke has the best burgers." Colin stared up at the sign above the diner. "But it says Williams Hardware," he said, pointing up at the sign as Rory grabbed his arm, leading him to the door. "Come on!" Once inside, Rory and Colin settled at a table. Colin began looking over the menu as Rory stared outside. "So... have you ever brought Logan here?" "How long have you been waiting to ask me that?" "Since we pulled up at the curb." "No. I've never brought Logan here. Logan's not a diner kind of a guy." "And I am?" "Maybe," Rory said, catching Colin's eye. They held each other's gazes, but the brief moment was halted when the door swung open and Lorelai Gilmore walked in, appearing beside their table. "Hi... you're not Logan," she said, her eyes landing upon Colin. "MOM!" Colin pushed back his chair, extending his hand to the vision that was Rory's mother. "Miss Gilmore. Hello. Colin McRae." Rory watched as her mother shook hands with Colin. "Nice to meet you, Colin." She turned her eyes on her daugher. "So, you didn't tell me that you were coming to town tonight." "It was just a spur of the moment thing. I was hungry so I came here." "And you brought Colin." "Yes, I did." Lorelai waited a beat, then asked the question that both Rory and Colin knew she was dying to ask. "Where's Logan?" "Mom," Rory warned. "What? I just figured..." "No." Colin surveyed the scene between the two women with mock interest. They obviously knew what one another was talking about whereas he did not. "I'm just... coffee all around?" "Yes," they both snapped at him as he stood up. "Be right back," he said, inching away from the table toward the counter. Sliding onto a stool, he waited for the burly guy in flannel to ask him for his order. "Three coffees, please," he said, glancing back at Rory and her mother in a heated conversation. "You know the Gilmore Girls?" Colin nodded. "I go to school with Rory." "Oh yeah? I'm Luke. I'm engaged to her mom." Colin exchanged handshakes with Luke. "Well, congratulations. Colin McRae. So you're the infamous Luke, huh?" "I wouldn't go as far as to say infamous." "No, you are. Rory talks about your food ALL the time. In fact, she never shuts up about it." From their table, Rory patted her mother's arm, encouraging Lorelai to be quiet, pointing out Luke and Colin conversing at the counter. "That's never happened with any of your boyfriends." "I know." "This Colin has super powers!" "He really does." "So what's the deal with the two of you?" Rory shrugged. "I'm not sure, really." "Rory, come on. You brought him here. He obviously means something to you." "Colin's a friend. A really good friend," she said with a lilt in her voice. "Ah ha!" Lorelai said, complete with finger point. "There it was! I knew it!" "You knew what?" "You like Colin." "What? I do not." "You do, too. You have the rosy cheeks and your voice gets all soft and lilty whenever you talk. You like him. It's okay. You're entitled." Rory cast a cautious glance at Colin, but he was still talking to Luke. She wondered what they were talking about. She returned her attention to her mother. "Am I, though? It hasn't been all that long since Logan and I broke up." "Honey, he dumped you, you're allowed to move on at your own leisure. However, moving on with one of his friends... I don't know the rules about that." "Colin's everything that Logan is not. He's not rich, but he is wealthy. He comes from a prominent family, but they're definitely not as prominent as the Huntzberger's. He's nice." "Logan's not nice?" "Colin's compassionate. That better?" "He does seem to be compassionate. And he fits around here. He doesn't stick out like a sore thumb like Logan would have." "Mom." "Well, it's true. Him with his blazers and slacks. Did the boy NOT own a pair of Levis?" Rory remained silent as Colin rejoined them with their coffees. He handed them out accordingly, then slipped back into his chair silently. "What?" he asked when he noticed that both women were staring at him. "You were gone awhile. Care to tell us what you and Luke were talking about up there?" Colin shook his head. "I'd rather not say." Rory glared at him, but said nothing further as he picked up his menu. "I have to be going," Lorelai told Rory and Colin. "Oh? Where are you off to?" "Luke promised to fix me dinner, that is if I can pull him away from work," Lorelai said as she stood up. She narrowed her eyes at Colin. "Colin, it was very nice to meet you. I hope we bump into one another again." "I can't agree more, Miss Gilmore." "Call me Lorelai." With a smile, she moved away from their table, meeting Luke at the counter, then disappeared with him in tow upstairs. "So, that was your mom?" "That was my mom." "She's nice. Not at all scary and bitchy, like Logan described." "He did not." "He did, too." "Hey Colin?" "Yeah?" "I'm glad we did this." "I am, too." "Let's order." "Yes. I'm starved." "This is nice," Colin said as he and Rory walked through the snow covered town. "It's like out of a movie." "I always thought that, too." "What was it like to grow up here? I bet it was surreal." "Not as surreal as boarding school in Switzerland, I'm sure." "Switzerland was nice, yes, but this... tell me about the small town life." "You really want to know?" "I don't know much about you so yes, I really want to know." "The PG version?" "I was the NC-17 version." "Okay, you asked for it," Rory said and began her tale.

Title: Torn Between Fandom: Gilmore Girls Rating: R Spoilers: None Disclaimer: I claim ownership to nothing. Summary: Sequel to Something Broken. Read that first or you'll be completely lost. Author's Note: Written for
Where to begin, how do I start At the moment love lit the spark Staring at the dawn, it's impossible to bear Endless longing hanging in the air
"You could be that guy, Colin. And I'd let you be that guy." Her words from the night before ring in my ear. Never before had such perfect words ever been uttered. The more conscientious side of me cajoles myself, baring a painful reminder that she was drunk and she had no control over what she was saying. But then there's that other part. The less logical part that told me that what she said did bare some truth. After all, Rory was more inclined to admit her feelings when she was drunk. She was more forthcoming with the truth. Not that it made the situation any easier. I don't want to be caught in the middle but I suddenly find myself stuck in exactly that place. Logan's one of my very best friends and I know how deeply he cares for Rory. I know he loves her on some sick level, but he IS Mitchum Huntzberger's son, after all. A lasting, committed relationship is not for him. Sure, Mitchum and Shira have been married for the last twenty-something years, but that's not to say that Mitchum was always faithful. We all knew he wasn't. Could Logan be different? Possibly. Was he any different? No. Logan was the spitting image of Mitchum in every way. He liked to rebel against his father, but that was only because he knew that they were so much alike. Of course, it didn't help that Logan was destined to rule the Huntzberger publishing empire. Mitchum stuck it to him every chance he could get as if he were in line to rule a country. If you ask me the Huntzberger's are nothing if not drama queens. And I'm a little tired of being upswept in all the chaos. Especially now that it concerns the sleeping beauty currently curled up in my sheets. I tried to leave. Really, I did. I didn't want to be a part of this. I didn't want to be involved in anything that I could regret tomorrow, but as I lay awake, listening to her steady breaths, I realize that I won't regret any of it. I can't. I've dreamt about this moment for entirely too long. I hear a door open, then close a few moments later. The sound of shoes hitting the floor make me sit up, but it's as Finn bellows, "Colin! Do you have a girl here?" that I fly out of bed. I quickly thrust on my bathrobe, then bolt out of the room before Finn happens to find that Rory is the girl that currently occupies my bed. He'll find out, I'll tell him myself, I just don't want him to wake her. When I step out of my room, I see him standing near the couch. He's staring at the black purse that I had thrown there when we had arrived. The contents had spilled out, revealing her student I.D. Eyebrow quirked, he turns to me. "Is she...?" he asks, pointing to my door. "Yes." "Did you...?" "I didn't intend to." "Does he...?" "No?!" "Are they still...?" I shrug my shoulders. "I'm not sure." "Didn't you ask?" I smile. "No. She was so persistent. I tried to resist, really, I did, but she..." "... wouldn't take no for an answer?" I shake my head. Finn eyes me curiously for a few moments, then his eyes bug out as he jumps to his feet. "You didn't want to turn her down." ....... I help her into the room and onto the bed, laying her down amongst the blankets. She's still hazy with sleep, muttering words I can't comprehend as I settle her in. As I'm leaving the room to bunk on the couch I hear her call my name. It's soft and sensual and makes every hair on the back of my neck stand up. Hesitantly I turn to her and a small gasp escapes my lips. I can't help it. She just looks so beautiful against the dark sheets. Her skin shines, glows, even. I have to touch her. I tamp down the urge to cross the room. My feet won't move. I'm paralyzed in the doorway. She kicks back the blankets, moving languidly across the room to me. "I want you to stay," she whispers, taking hold of my hands. "Rory...," I needed it to come out hard and demanding, but instead it comes out soft, more like a sigh--a surrender. Yeah, that's what I need to be doing right now, surrendering myself to Rory Gilmore. She reaches up to touch my cheek. I close my eyes as her fingers outline the contours of my face. "I meant what I said earlier," she whispers. "I do want you to be that guy. I want you to be that guy, tonight." My eyes snap open. "We can't." Her eyes widen, then drop to my waist. "We... can't?" she asks, noting my sudden arousal. I try not to, but, I smile. I fucking smile then she advances on me and that's it. Every rebuttal that I had quickly disappears and all that remains are the two of us. I kick the door closed and we share a smile before our lips finally collide and it's the most amazing thing ever. I sound like a gushing schoolgirl, but I've laid awake in bed nights just wondering how soft her lips were, how she tasted... And now? It's even better than I had imagined. Every fantasy, every daydream doesn't compare to the real thing. Her hands are quick and demanding. And tantalizing. Oh so fucking tantalizing. I wish they weren't but every brush of her hand, every agonizingly tender touch engulfs me in a fire that I cannot escape. I find her zipper quickly as she reaches for the buttons on my shirt. "I'm glad that you've stopped wearing those damn vests, Colin." "You noticed?" "Yeah. Yeah, I did," she whispers as she pulls me on top of her down on the mattress. ....... Sitting at the counter in the kitchen, Finn asks, "So what are you going to do? You fucked Gilmore. Logan's not gonna be a bit happy about that." "She found out about Logan's extracurriculars during Thanksgiving." "Oh," Finn says. "What if you're just...," he begins to ask. "Revenge?" I supply. "Yeah, I thought of that." It was going to be an interesting afternoon, she thought as she rang the doorbell.

Rory smiled warmly when Colin opened the door, dripping wet. "What happened to you?" she asked as he ushered her inside.

"Finn thought it would be funny to throw play the fun game of 'Wet the Cook' and I just so happened to be the cook so he got an added laugh by throwing me into the pool."

"Get upstairs! You're dripping water all over the floor!" Stephanie yelled from behind them.

"I'm going! I'm going," he muttered under his breath, once again smirking at Rory as he said, "I'll see you outside in a few minutes."

Colin began ascending the stairs as Stephanie took her arm, pulling her into the kitchen. "So, how are you?"

"I'm fine."

"And Logan?"

"Logan's, uh, good, I guess. Why don't you ask him yourself."

"Because I'm asking you."

Rory plopped her purse down on the kitchen counter. "Are you plying me for information?"

"Yes," Stephanie said with a strangled breath. "Logan's a sourpuss. He won't tell me anything."

"Then, I'm not going to either," Rory said, turning on her heel. She headed toward the back door with Stephanie quick at her heels.

"That's not fair!" Stephanie said, bumping into Rory as she stopped in the doorway. "What are you looking at?" she asked, following Rory's line of vision.

"I didn't know that Francesca was going to be here."

"Finn invited her."

"Why?"

"Hell if I know. Why does Finn do the things that he does?" Rory stepped out into the backyard as Stephanie asked, "Hey, you okay?"

Rory stopped, turning around to face Stephanie. "Yeah, I'm fine. I was just surprised to see her here is all."

"I know you better than that. What's going on? I thought that you and her were okay? After that whole birthday party you helped orchestrate for her back in March, I just figured that the two of you had mended fences."

"We did, I just...," Rory turned around so that her back was facing Logan who was engaged in a conversation with Francesca.

"What?" Stephanie asked when Rory didn't finish her sentence.

"I accused Logan of sleeping with her," Rory spat out quickly.

"I'm sorry, you did what?"

"I don't know what I was thinking! We were at dinner and he was... he was being an ass, so I insinuated that his business dinners with Francesca were far from platonic."

"Oh, Rory...," Stephanie sighed.

"I know."

"Francesca has no interest in Logan."

"How do you know that? I don't even know that."

"She's dating Finn," Stephanie blurted out.

Confusion washed across Rory's face. "Huh?"

"They've been seeing one another for the last few months, but they kept it under wraps because Francesca works for Logan and they didn't want to complicate Francesca and Logan's working relationship in case things didn't pan out but since they're getting serious, they told him. And Finn told us and then he just showed up here with her today."

"Wow," Rory said, turning around to look at Finn. "Finn hasn't been serious about a girl since Rosemary."

"It seriously broke his heart when he found out that she was seeing Robert behind his back...," Stephanie added, then, said, "But you're changing the subject!"

"I can't go over there and pretend to be nice, Stephanie."

"Sure you can," Stephanie said, pushing Rory in the direction of Logan and Francesca. "Just remember. She's sleeping with Finn and not your husband," Stephanie whispered.

"Thanks. That helps a lot."

Logan and Francesca were laughing when they joined them. Logan's face lit up at the sight of Rory, as did hers. "I was wondering when you were going to get here," he said as Finn emerged from the pool bellowing, "Frannie, love, where did I put my drink?"

"Is he drunk?"

"It's Finn. When is he ever not?" Logan asked, pulling her away. "Are you okay?"

"Of course. Why wouldn't I be?"

"I just figured what with Francesca here..."

"Now, why would you say something like that?"

Logan just shrugged. "No reason I just thought...," he began.

"Should I feel uncomfortable, Logan?" she interrupted, her voice hinged with a haughty tone.

"Rory, no. You know that...," he began to say.

She cut him off before he could finish his thought. "I know. I do." She sighed. "I want to forget that horrible dinner ever happened. And what we said... can we just forget that? Please?" she pleaded.

He smiled at her. At least she wanted to make a valiant effort. "Sure, we can do that." He began leading her in the direction of the drinks cart. "We came here to have a nice afternoon with our friends. Let's try to do that, hmm?"

 

After Finn and Francesca had made an early departure and Colin and Stephanie began arguing about the wet clothes that he'd left on the bathroom floor, Rory and Logan announced their leave before any blood was shed.

Rory linked her arm through his as he politely walked her to her car. Always the distinguished gentleman. "I'm glad you came," he told her as they made their way down the sidewalk.

"Me too. It's been ages since we've all hung out like this."

"Years," he agreed. He, Colin and Finn had been hanging out lately, but they were keeping an eye on him. Probably by Stephanie's orders. Stephanie was the anchor. Back in junior high school when he and Colin had fought over who was going to ask Casey Shelton to the prom, it was Stephanie who had gotten them talking again. When he and Rory had gone their separate ways before his graduation, she had done her damnedest to get them speaking again.

As she opened her car door, she turned to look at him. "I'm sure I'll talk to you at one point during the week."

"I'm sure you will," he said with a wide smirk. "Maybe we can get together for lunch sometime this week."

"To talk, right?"

He smiled at her in answer.

"Right," she said, inwardly groaning. Talking meant disrupting the balance that they had going. Talking meant drudging up their less than perfect marriage. Talking meant telling him exactly how he made her feel and if there was one thing that she didn't want to do, it was upset Logan any further and any talking that they did would only do that.

"There's only so long that we can put it off."

"I know. I just... we're getting along. It's nice. I just don't want to screw it all up."

"You won't," he said, bracing her arms with his hands for reassurance. A surge of heat swept through her at the feel of his hands on her.

Logan caught the unsettled look in her eyes, causing him to drop his hands and step back. "So, uh, drive safe."

"Yeah. Right. Umm... you, too. And I'll... bye," she said abruptly. She climbed into her car, gunned the engine and with a smile flashed at Logan, she sped away, stopping at the stop sign at the end of the block to rest her head against the steering wheel.

This reconciliation got harder everyday, she thought as she turned left and headed back for her hotel.

 

Logan took a seat at the bar, signaling for the bartender. "Whiskey on the rocks," he ordered, lifting his eyes to the television suspended from the ceiling.

He tapped his knuckles on the bar, looking around. The air was damp, holding the stench of a mixture of booze and cheap cologne. He stuck out like a sore thumb in his Armani suit, but he didn't care. He needed an escape from the real world. He didn't need to think about what his wife what doing at that particular moment.

Who she was doing it with.

He shook his head to get that train of thought out of his head.

He had called her earlier to say that he was going to be late for dinner at her grandparents house only to have her tell him that she wasn't going to be able to make it. She had other plans and had informed her grandmother of them earlier in the week. She had apologized profusely for not telling him. Things had been hectic at work. She quickly explained that a friend needed her help. Then he'd heard it.

The man's voice.

"Rory, I need a towel and there's none left in the bathroom."

"I forgot to get more from housekeeping," she laughed. "Let me go and do that." She had quickly turned her attention back to him, not bothering to explain why there was a man in her bathroom. "Logan, I have to go. We'll catch up next week sometime."

That was the first conversation that they'd had since their awkward moment Sunday afternoon.

The pull was electric, he thought. He knew she felt it, too. He knew that she did. That was probably her reason for leaving so abruptly. She wasn't ready for things to be that easy between them yet. She would barely spend five minutes alone in his presence. They always met in a restaurant or somewhere where they were surrounded by people.

She was scared to be alone with him. Really alone with him and he wanted to know why.

The bartender set his drink before him. Logan thanked him as he stared down into the colored liquid.

She was close yet still so very far away.

He needed... he didn't know what he needed. He needed her that much was certain, but she'd erected a wall around herself to keep him at arm's length.

That's what had brought him here. He needed time away from the house, away from his office to think.

However, the only thing he kept thinking about was his wife in a hotel with another man.

It made his head hurt.

He couldn't afford jealousy. Not after the downfall of their marriage. He couldn't be that kind of guy. He'd been that guy so very long ago and the repercussions had been dastardly.

He felt someone fall onto the stool beside him. He curbed the impulse to turn to see who it was as he knocked back his drink, quickly ordering another to follow.

"Hey stranger," came the voice from the chair beside him.

He turned his head, his eyes landing on the woman beside him.

He smiled. She wasn't the woman that he wanted to spend his night with, but she'd do. "Can I buy you a drink?"

Emily Gilmore stepped off the elevator with established poise, setting her eyes on the bumbling secretary as she made her way down the long corridor. "Excuse me?"

The young woman looked up, smacking annoyingly on the bubblegum in her mouth. "Yes. May I help you?"

"I'm here to talk to Logan Huntzberger."

"Mister Huntzberger asked not to be disturbed this morning."

"I don't care what Mister Huntzberger asked of you. I demand to speak with him," Emily demanded, already annoyed with the little secretarial twit.

"One moment," the secretary said, picking up her phone. "Mister Huntzberger, there's a woman here demanding to speak with you."

Emily snatched the phone out of the young girl's hand. "Logan, it's Emily. I'm sorry to have dropped in like this, but I need to speak with you."

"Emily, uh, hi. Sure. Have Megan point the way."

Emily handed Megan back the phone. "Which way is his office, dear?"

 

 

"Emily this is such a pleasant surprise," Logan greeted her at the doorway with a kiss to her cheek.

"I was in the area," she lied as he led her to the chair in front of his desk. She'd come here on a mission and she was not leaving until she had completed that mission. Rory and Logan may be willing to throw their marriage away, but she wasn't just going to stand around and let them. The two of them had fought too hard, experienced too much together to call it quits now.

"Can I get you something to drink? Water? Soda? Coffee?" Logan asked as he moved back around his desk.

"No, no. I'm fine."

"Okay, well, what can I do for you, then?"

"I came to talk about Rory."

Logan sighed as he fell into his chair. "I was afraid you'd say that."

"This separation is absurd, Logan. You have to do something."

"I've tried."

"Well, try harder."

"It's not that simple."

"Make it that simple. I will not stand by and watch the two of you throw away this marriage."

"Emily you can't even call what Rory and I have a marriage. You can barely call it a relationship."

"But you love each other."

"Sometimes love ain't enough."

"Well, it should be. I expect to see you at Friday Night Dinner."

"Oh, I don't know...," Logan began to object. He had promised to give Rory her space and to show up at Friday Night Dinner... he didn't want to put her in that predicament.

"You're a part of this family and you're going to start partaking in family tradition, including Friday Night Dinner. Rory knows that you're coming and is perfectly fine with it."

"She is?"

"Would I lie?"

He gave her a skeptical look, but managed to muster up, "No, I guess you wouldn't."

"Dinner is at seven. Be there at six."

"Yes, ma'am."

"I have to be going. I'll see you Friday."

 

 

"So how's work?" Richard asked as he and Rory joined Lorelai and Christopher in the living room for drinks.

"Fine," Rory said settling down onto the couch. "Actually, I was offered a job working in Boston."

"Boston?" Emily and Richard asked in unison.

"Doing what?" Richard asked.

"Heading up an arts and leisure magazine."

"Are you going to take it?"

Rory shook her head. "I doubt it. As much as I would love to relocate after the divorce I just don't think Boston is the place for me. Plus, I love the Centennial. I'd be crazy to give up my job as editor now."

Rory watched the face her grandmother made. Emily was unhappy with her separation from Logan, a feeling that she had expressed at length over the past few weeks during her numerous phone calls and visits.

When the doorbell rang, Rory exchanged a look with her parents, then with her grandfather. "Is someone else joining us?"

"I have no idea. No telling who your grandmother invited."

"Hey everyone. Sorry I'm late," Logan said, walking into the living room, stopping when the maid appeared to take his coat. "Traffic was horrible," he said taking in all of the surprised faces, especially Rory's.

Rory sat still for a few moments, surprised and confused as to why he was there, but then it sunk in: her grandmother. After a few moments, she said as she stood up, "Well, you're here now. A drink?"

He nodded his head. "Yeah," he said, following her to the drink cart.

He watched as she poured him a club soda. "Here you go."

"Thanks," he said, taking the glass from her. They moved to the sofa, sitting down only to have the maid announce that dinner was ready a few moments later.

Logan made his way into the dining room as Lorelai pulled Rory aside. "Did you know that he was going to be here?"

"Of course not. And we both know who was behind it." They glared at Emily as she walked in from the kitchen.

"Stop loitering in the hall, you two," Emily snapped. "You don't want your dinner to get cold."

Lorelai and Rory exchanged a look, then moved into the dining room.

Rory settled beside Logan as he placed his napkin on his lap, muttering an, "I'm sorry," under his breath as the maid entered the room with their first course.

 

"You don't have to apologize," Rory said later that evening after they had stepped outside, ready to leave.

"I told you I was going to give you space and then... I thought you knew I was coming."

Rory shook her head. "No. I didn't," she said, pulling her coat tighter around her body. "But that's not to say that I didn't enjoy having you here tonight."

Logan stared at her dubiously as she began walking to her car, "I've been expecting her to meddle. It's what she does. She can't just leave well enough alone."

"I know this made you uncomfortable. I won't come back unless you want me to."

Rory dropped her eyes. "It's not that I don't want you around, Logan, it's not that at all."

"What is it, then?"

Rory sighed. "This is all... it's hard."

"You're making it harder on yourself by fighting it." Logan leaned against the hood of his car as he said, "You act like you hate me, but we sat beside each other tonight like it was the most normal thing in the world. We didn't argue. We didn't throw barbs at one another. It was like old times, Rory."

"Don't read too much into it. It was just dinner," she bit back, sarcastically. Why did she do that? They could be having a normal conversation and she always had to act like a bitter bitch.

Logan ignored her sarcasm. He had gotten used to her decisive attitude the last few weeks. Sooner or later she'd soften. "A dinner that neither of us walked out of," he pointed out.

Logan did have a point. They both sat back and enjoyed dinner. They had a few glasses of wine with dinner. They talked amiably with her parents and her grandparents. It was nice. It reminded her of the times that they'd attended the weekly dinners together before they were married. "What are you getting at?" she finally asked.

"Maybe we should try it again."

"What? Dinner?"

"Or something like it. Maybe lunch instead."

"Brunch?" she found herself offering.

"That could work." Logan pushed himself away from his car, stopping in front of Rory. He bent his knees to make her look at him. "And we'll actually talk this time?"

She nodded. "Yes."

"How's Sunday?"

"Yeah... Sunday sounds fine."

"About eleven? At the Yacht Club?"

"I'll meet you there."

 

 

At the yacht club Sunday morning, Rory had arrived first, taking advantage of her early arrival to drink a mimosa and delve into the morning paper. She was halfway through the world news when she heard Logan's voice.

She glanced up from the paper, spotting Logan near the doorway, chatting with the patrons and some of the other guests. She recognized one particular person as Matt McDermott, a close friend of Shira and Mitchum's. She watched Logan for a few moments, smiling as she watched the polished charm pull through, even to people that he didn't like.

And Logan didn't like Matt McDermott, something that he had told her every time he and Matt crossed paths. Matt was his father's people. Not his, he had told her once.

When he glanced in her direction and caught her watching him, he smiled. She couldn't help but return his smile, then quickly averted her eyes back to the paper while he continued his conversation.

He joined her nearly fifteen minutes later, sliding into the chair across from her with a casual, "Hey."

"You pulled yourself away from your fans long enough to come and see me? I'm honored," she teased as she refolded her newspaper, putting it aside.

"I should know better than to come here," he said taking a sip from the glass of water that stood on the table in front of him.

"We can leave."

Logan shook his head, relaxing in his chair. "No, we're here now. We're not leaving because of <i>them</i>."

"Them? You mean the pod people," she teased.

"They just as soon be pod people. They're Mitchum Huntzberger people. They're pretty much the same thing."

"Logan, you shouldn't let them get to you. You shouldn't let your father get to you."

"I know, Rory, but it's easier said than done, you know."

"Yeah, I know."

Logan let out a deep breath. "I don't want to talk about my parents or their people. We came to talk about us, didn't we?"

"We did."

"Let's talk about that."

"Okay. But do you mind if we order first? I'm starving."

Logan chuckled softly as he opened his menu. "Let's order, then."

 

 

An hour later, Rory and Logan sat in front of their cleaned off plates, laughing and reminiscing about their relationship. "Remember when we all went to Colorado and Finn fell off the lift and his pants fell off?"

"That's something I would rather not remember. Stephanie and I had seen way too much of Finn on that particular day. I wish I could get that image out of my head."

"Hey now! I would rather not think of you thinking of Finn in any capacity, much less a half-naked one."

"Finn's a decent looking guy, Logan. I mean, I wouldn't be a woman if I didn't think he wasn't the least bit attractive."

Logan paused as he was about to take a sip of his coffee. "Tell me that you're kidding. You aren't honestly attracted to Finn, are you?"

Rory shrugged, nonchalantly. "Maybe."

He caught her teasing tone. "Not funny."

"Just a little."

"Do you see me laughing?"

"No. And it makes this awfully hard to revel in."

"Would you rather I act jealous and threaten to beat Finn to a bloody pulp?"

"Yes, actually, I would."

"Well, I will if it would prove to you that I love you and would be willing to do anything to make you see that."

The playfulness was gone. It was serious time now. "Logan..."

"Rory we've been tiptoeing around this all morning. We came here to talk. Let's talk."

"Fine," she said, relenting.

"I know that there's no way to undo the last three years. The damage is done."

"I agree."

"But there is a way to make it better."

"I don't see how, Logan. I don't know you. You don't know me. We haven't spent time alone in... it's been THAT long. Work has become our spouses. How do we try to maintain a relationship, a marriage, despite all this? I just don't see how we can do that."

"I've been thinking about this a lot. The only rational solution I can come up with is for us to start over."

"Start over?"

"Clean slate. Pretend that we don't know each, which, honestly, we no longer do."

He had put a lot of thought into this, she conceded and she had to admit, that she was intrigued by whatever it was that he had planned. "What are you proposing, exactly?"

"What do people normally do when they try to get to know one another?"

Rory shrugged, not catching his drift. "I don't know... date?"

"Precisely."

"You want to date me?" she asked, incredulous. Her husband wanted to date her. God, it sounded more insane in her head. "Logan, that's ridiculous."

"Is it?" He reached across the table to take her hand. "The way I see it this is our best option. We're separated anyway, right?"

"Right," she agreed with a nod of her head.

"It'll be like the old days. We'll go out, have dinner, maybe take in a movie and you'll reject me like you used to. It'll be great."

"Um, sorry, but if anyone did rejecting it was you," she reminded him.

"Good point. That'll be the only X factor here. You won't have to worry about being rejecting. I, on the other hand, will be doing all the worrying for the both of us."

"You're serious about this?"

"Very. I want to make this work. I want to make it better. And if this is how low I have to stoop to get your trust back, then, well, I'm going to do whatever it takes."

"Logan, I don't know, this is too much for me to take in. I mean... <i>dating</i>? We already did that."

"Poorly, if I must say."

"Granted, we weren't the best at it."

"We'll do it right this time, Rory."

Rory saw the hopeful look in his eyes. She knew that look. She had saw that look so many times. He'd had the exact same look in his eyes the night that he'd proposed. "On one condition."

"Anything."

"No casual dating."

Chapter Three: Blowing Off Steam "I didn't know there was a mini-golf in New Haven," Colin said as they left the mini-golf course. Rory was limping, no thanks to him, who had hit her with a golf club. He had a really bad swing. And she'd been standing in a really bad place. "Marty and I had stumbled across it one night. We came here pretty often to blow off some steam." "So were you visualizing that Logan was the ball?" She snickered. "Whatever do you mean?" He laughed. "Okay, so I'm really sorry about your knee." "As you've said a thousand times. It's okay. I just thought that you country boy types are bred for golf." Colin shook his head. "We're not. My father was never a big golfer. He would go to the country club to sway the ladies. Usually the other members' wives." "Your dad sounds like a prime catch." "He is," he scoffed. "He's already traded in Heidi so no telling who he'll have at the house when I go for Christmas." "Oh, Colin, I'm so sorry." He shrugged. "As long as I'm not there to see it, I can care less what he does." As they arrived at the car, Colin said, "Hand me your keys." "Why?" "Because your knee is hurt. I'll drive. At least back to Yale." She handed Colin her keys, smiling, as she said, "Thank you." He then helped her around the car and into the passenger side seat. After he and Rory had said their goodbyes, complete with an awkward hug and an even more awkward look afterwards, Colin had headed back to his apartment, not prepared to find Finn and Logan roused in a game of Playstation. "Where have you been?" Finn asked, not taking his eyes off the game as he closed the door behind himself. "Out," he said simply. "We're meeting the Thompson twins later," Logan said, turning around to glance at him. "You wanna come?" Colin shook his head. "No. I have to start studying for finals. I'm actually gonna do that now," he said, making his way to his room. Finn and Logan began to object. "Hang out with us," Finn declared. "We haven't seen you for the last few days. "Yeah, where have you been?" Logan asked. "Around," Colin said vaguely. "As much as I would love to stay out here and play another rousing game of Fight Night with the two of you, I can't." Colin retired to his room, closing and locking the door behind himself. He leaned against the door for a few moments listening to Finn and Logan exchange theories as to what his problem was. He crossed to his desk, and as he began sifting through the books on his desk, his cell phone rang. He dug it out of his pocket, answering, "Hello?" Anyone was a welcome distraction from studying. "So, I was thinking..." He smiled, recognizing her voice. "About what?" "That you owe me. You hit me with a golf ball so I expect clemency." "Do you?" "I do. The whole nine yards and all." "The whole nine yards, huh?" "Yeah. It's only fair." "I do believe that nine yards could be arranged." Colin had made reservations at a restaurant in Hartford that came highly recommended by a girl in his English class. He wanted to impress Rory, but he didn't want to throw his money in her face like Logan had done during their time together. As he stepped out of his class, he grabbed his phone, dialing her number. He frowned when he got a busy signal. When he broke through the double doors and got outside, he headed in the direction of the coffee cart, having been denied his caffeine fix all day. It was as he gave his order that his phone began ringing. "You always call when I'm in the shower. Do you have a complex?" "Huh?" "Do you sit and class and wonder what I'm doing and it just hits you, well, maybe Rory's in the shower? Let me call and see?" "No," he says, exchanging his money for his coffee. He finds her neurosis endearing. She sighs. "I was thinking about you, though. Hence the call." "That's nice to hear." "I was sitting in class and the professor was lecturing about women in third world countries and I was thinking about you. Naked. In the shower." She scoffed. "Now, you're just mocking me!" Colin couldn't help but laugh. He loved rifling her feathers. "I would do no such thing." "Did you call me with an intent in mind?" "Just to remind you that I'll be picking you up Friday at six-thirty." "Okay." Rory waited for him to say something else. Anything else. But Colin wasn't big on the small talk. She usually had to draw the words out of his mouth. Maybe he didn't trust her. Maybe he couldn't trust her because of her long standing relationship with his best friend. But that was ridiculous. Colin wasn't that kind of person. Was he? After a few moments, she said, "Colin, I hate to cut this conversation short, but I have to get dressed." "Right." "I have to be at the paper in an hour." "Yeah, sure." "But I'll see you Friday?" "Friday it is," he agreed. "Bye Colin." "Bye Rory," Colin said as he began his trek toward the parking lot. Rory couldn't concentrate. The more she typed away at her computer trying to type out her article, the more her mind went back to Colin. She'd been thinking about him a lot lately. She'd be doing something as simple as watching television and a commercial would come on or a song would play that would remind her of him. "Oh, you have it bad, Gilmore," she muttered to herself. "Talking to your computer?" Rory turned in her chair, surprised to see Logan standing behind her. She remained silent. "Still mad at me, huh?" Rory returned to her computer. "I have nothing to be mad at you for. You're a blip on my radar, Logan." "Of course. I'm just here running errands for my father. I saw you and thought I'd say hi." She looked at him. "Next time do me a favor and curb that impulse." Rory stood up abruptly and began walking away from him. "Would you wait?" he asked, falling into step behind her. "No, I will not." She spun around to face him. "We," she said, with a motion of her hand between them, "are no longer dating. We aren't even friends. So I don't have to bend at your will. I don't have to talk to you. I don't have to be nice to you. And I certainly do not have to stop just because you say so." Logan looked around, realizing that they had conjured an audience. "I'm sorry that I...," he began to apologize. She held up her hand. "Do not even finish that sentence," she warned. "I don't need your apologies or your lame ass excuses. I'm done." She turned to face the secretary. "Peggy, I'm leaving early." "Sure thing, sweetie." Rory turned on her heel and headed for the elevator. She pressed a button, then stepped inside, glaring at Logan as the doors closed in front of her. She pressed the button to go down, pulling her phone from her belt clip. As she dialed the number, her hand shook. She smiled as the line clicked. "I need to see you..."

"Yes, but when you talk shop with me I don't listen."

Lorelai pushed herself to her feet as she flicked off the television. "I want coffee. Do you want coffee?" 

"At eight o'clock at night? I think not. I'll be up all night if I drink any," he yelled after her as she made her way into the kitchen.

"Maybe that was the point."

"Why, are you planning on taking advantage of me?"

"Hmm, well, yes, that was the plan."

"Stop talking so that I can finish my work, then."

"Okay."

Lorelai was finishing setting up the coffee pot when she heard the front door open and close, followed by Rory beckoning, "Mom?"

"Rory?" Lorelai walked into the foyer where her daughter was standing, a pair of strappy shoes in one hand, a beaded purse in the other. Her mascara streaked face was a sign that she'd been crying. "Honey, what's wrong?"

Lorelai barely got the words out before Rory began crying again, seeking her mother's arms for comfort. From his perch on the sofa, Christopher closed his laptop, setting it on the coffee table. "I'll make up the spare room," he told Lorelai before he disappeared upstairs.

Rory pushed away from Lorelai. "I'm sorry to have just shown up. I just didn't want to go back to my hotel room."

"It's okay. You know you can stay here as long as you want. Your Dad and I would love it if you stayed here. Gigi would, too," Lorelai said, leading Rory upstairs.

"I know, and thanks. I may take you up on that."

"You gonna tell Mommy what happened?"

Rory nodded her head. "Just not tonight. I have a really bad headache and I just... I just want to go to sleep if that's okay."

"It's fine, sweetie. Dad's making up the bed for you. Go meet him and you can climb right into bed."

"Thanks for understanding, Mom."

Rory left her mother standing on the stairs to head in the direction of the spare room, stopping first to peek into GiGi's room before moving onto her room for the night. Her dad was turning down the sheets when she walked in. "Hey," she said, falling into the large ottoman in the corner.

"Hey kiddo. Rough night?"

"You could say that."

"A bender gone horribly awry?" Christopher tried to joke. He wasn't trying to make light of the situation. If anything he wanted to see his daughter smiling again, something she hadn't done since after she had married Logan.

When she began sobbing again, Christopher quickly crossed the room to her, gathering her in his arms. "Oh, Rory, honey, it's going to be okay. You're going to be okay. I can't say the same for Logan, however." He smiled, kissing her forehead when she began laughing.

"Thanks Daddy," she said kissing his cheek. After a few moments of silence, she asked, "How'd you know it was about Logan?"

Christopher hugged her closer. "I just figured." Patting her leg, he said, "Come on. Let's get you into bed." Christopher helped her over toward the bed, tucking her in like he never got to do when she was younger. "Night honey," he told his daughter, kissing her forehead before he made his way toward the door.

"Hey Dad?"

"Yeah?"

"Thanks." Chris turned off the light as he watched her roll over to get some much needed sleep. 

He wasn't surprised to find Lorelai waiting outside the door when he exited the room. "How is she?"

"Tired, I would guess," he said, leading her into their bedroom. Closing the door, he began to strip for bed. "What's going on, Lorelai? I feel so out of the loop with all of this. You told me that she had left, but her showing up here crying and upset is something that I hadn't anticipated."

"She's taking this really hard, Chris. She doesn't want to give up, but thinks she'll be spinning her wheels for nothing if she goes back to him."

"She tell you that?"

Lorelai shook her head. "Colin did. Rory seldom tells me what's going on. I'm surprised she told me that she was leaving."

They climbed into bed, Lorelai snuggling in close to Chris. "Then, what do we do? Just standby and watch her continue to be miserable."

"Yeah."

"I was afraid you'd say that," Christopher said sarcastically. "I don't like this, you know."

"I know."

Christopher looked at Lorelai, frowning. "I guess we have to go to sleep, huh?"

Lorelai smacked him with the pillow. "Your side of the bed, mister," she instructed, smiling to herself as he groaned, rolling over onto his side. 

 

 

Rory heard the door open way before she was pushed awake. "Rory," came the whisper. "Rory," it came again. "RORY!!!"

Rory sat upright, not used to being awakened by a rowdy seven year old. "Gigi... hi. What time is it?"

Gigi just shrugged her shoulders. "I dunno."

"Where's Dad?"

"I dunno."

"Where's my mom?"

"I dunno."

"Do you know anything?"

Gigi was silent a moment as she pondered Rory's question, but only shrugged. "Why are you wearing a dress?"

Rory looked down, noticing that she was still wearing her dress from her dinner with Logan. "I... uh... I don't have any pajamas."

"Where's Logan?"

"There you are!" Christopher barged into the room, setting his sights on Gigi. "Come downstairs and leave your sister alone."

"No, Dad, it's fine," Rory insisted.

"Really?"

"Really."

"I was asking Rory where Logan was. Did he sleep here too?"

Rory exchanged a look with her father, thankful that he came to her rescue. "No, honey. He had to work."

"But he's always working," Gigi whined as Chris lifted her off the bed, setting her on her feet beside the bed.

"I know," Chris said as he began leading Gigi out of the room.

Rory took a moment to get herself together, then made her way out of the room and downstairs. Her parents were gathered at the table with Gigi, her mother pouring Gigi a bowl of cereal. 

"You're awake," Lorelai said as she walked into the kitchen. "How'd you sleep?"

"Horrible," Rory said, pulling up a chair at the table.

"Yeah, that bed isn't comfortable at all," her dad added.

"You sleep in it often?"

"Your mom snores."

"I do not!"

"Yes, you do," Rory agreed, laughing along with her dad.

Lorelai settled at the table beside Gigi. "Traitor!" she said, glaring at Rory. 

Chris stood up from the table abruptly. "Hurry up, Gee. Finish your breakfast so that we can go."

"Go?" Rory asked. "Where are you going?"

"I'm taking Gigi up to see Sherry in Boston. She has a few days off of school so Sherry wanted to spend some time with her."

Rory and Lorelai took turns hugging Gigi before Chris carted her off towards the door, wheeling her bag after him.

After Chris and Gigi were gone, Lorelai focused on her daughter. "Now, about last night...," Lorelai began.

"Mom, seriously, we're doing this now?" she asked with a sigh, sitting back in her chair.

"Yes, we're doing this now."

"I'd rather not do this at all."

"Rory, we have to talk about this."

"No, we don't. I'm not sixteen anymore," Rory said defiantly, pushing back her chair.

"I wish you'd tell me what's going on, but you don't tell me anything."

"I can't. I wish you'd understand that. I just... I don't want to talk about this."

"Why not?"

"Because it's my problem. You can't fix it. I have to fix it and I don't know how."

"Rory..."

"Mom! No! I don't want any advice. I just... I need to figure out what I need, what I want... just let me do that. Please."

"Okay."

"I'm sorry for just showing up last night," Rory apologized. 

"You're always welcome here, Rory. Anytime. We're here for you, kid."

"I know, Mom. I just needed to get out of Hartford, out of the same city as Logan so I came home. I didn't want to be at the hotel by myself."

"You need to talk to him, Rory. Really talk to him. Not just throw barbs at him."

"I know, but every time we talk or we come face-to-face, we both do it. It's not just me." With a sigh, Rory fell back into her chair, admitting, "We had dinner last night."

Lorelai sunk into her chair. "Wow."

"Not really, no. He found out about the shellfish."

"Oh."

"That wasn't his reaction. He was hurt that I didn't call him."

"But he wasn't around."

"That's what I told him. I made everything so much worse," Rory said, running her fingers through her hair. "I told him that there were things that he kept from me. I even insinuated that he was having an affair with Francesca."

"Oh, Rory...," Lorelai began.

"I KNOW. Terrible, right? Francesca's a friend of mine. I mean, how could I even say that?"

"You're hurting, honey."

"It's no excuse, Mom. Logan would never... he would never accuse me of something that. All the time that I spend with Colin... he could try to insinuate something there. But he doesn't."

"Because Logan trusts you."

"I trust him."

Lorelai shook her head. "No, honey. No you don't. You never really have."

Rory stared at her mother. Lorelai was right. She had never truly trusted Logan. There was always a twinge of doubt in the back of her mind at how loyal to her he truly and if he truly loved her. She always wanted to believe the best in him, but sometimes he made it very difficult.

 

 

After Rory had gotten back to her hotel and showered, she sat on her bed, staring hard at her cell phone. With a deep breath, she pressed two buttons and waited.

 

 

Logan was sitting on the porch in the backyard with Colin and Finn, sharing a bottle of whiskey with his best friends. "Logan your phone's ringing," Colin told him. 

Logan moved from his chair, walking back into the house to retrieve the phone. "Hello?" he answered.

"Hey... it's me."

"Rory... hi. I wasn't expecting you to call."

"After the way I took off last night I wasn't expecting you to, either."

"Yeah... so, um, is something wrong?"

"No, not really. I thought I was okay with this, Logan. I thought I was ready."

"But you're not?"

"No."

"So, you're calling to tell me, what? That you need more time? More space? I've given you time. I've given you all the space you need."

"Logan, I just... I can't, okay? Understand that. I need you to understand that."

"I do, Rory. I do understand." Logan let out a sigh. "I'll leave you alone."

"I'm not asking...," she began to say.

"No," he said quickly, cutting her off. "You want space, I'll give you space. After last night I think we both need time to really think about what we're doing here. We can't keep throwing the past back at one another."

"You're right about that."

"We'll give it time," he said. "Which is good because I'm leaving town tomorrow."

"Big story?"

"Something like that," he answered vaguely.

"I guess I'll talk to you whenever you get back then."

"Of course."

"Have fun. And Logan?"

"Yeah?"

"Be careful. Please."

"I will."

Logan hung up the phone as Colin walked into the kitchen, holding the empty bottle of whiskey. "Who was on the phone?"

"Oh, um, it was Rory."

"You tell her about Atlantic City?"

Logan shrugged. "Nah. It's not her scene, you know. Plus, it's just us guys."

"And Stephanie."

"I forget that you can't go anywhere without her."

"Don't let her hear you say that."

"Do you want me talk to her?" Colin offered.

Logan shook his head. "This decision has to be hers, Colin. Thank you for talking to her, but look where it got us. Right back where we started. I'll give her space and hopefully then she'll be ready to really try to work this out."

Logan reached into a cabinet, taking out a fresh bottle of whiskey, glancing out the window at Finn. "Come on," he told Colin as he moved toward the door. "Finn's chasing a squirrel. Let's go save him from himself."

"As if we have those powers," Colin said as he followed Logan outside.



Emily Gilmore sat in her living room, thumbing through the Monday morning newspaper. She'd been gone over a week and was catching up on current events. 

When she saw that Rory had made the paper, she smiled. Normally seeing her granddaughter in the paper excited her, but on this day, in this particular article, the excitement was gone.

Rory had been interviewed for an expose as the editor-in-chief of the Hartford Centennial. She'd acquired the position nearly a year earlier, after having worked at the Centennial since before her graduation. Rory talked about her previous work as a reporter for the Centennial, then to her promotion after her boss retired. She tried diligently to dodge all personal questions, but the one question that she did answer was to say that her and her husband were going through a trying time and were undergoing a trial separation. No decisions had been made yet.

Emily tossed the paper onto the table in front of her, debating her next move. She leapt off the couch, grabbed her keys and purse bellowing, "Richard! I'm going to town!" as she made her way to the door.

She was going to resolve this once and for all. She was not going to let Rory and Logan ruin their marriage. Not if she had anything to say about it.
