When things begin to slip away, what to you do? You return to the beginning and start anew. It was Monday, and boy did she hate Mondays. She detested them. Her first instinct was always to crawl back under the covers and pretend that it was still Sunday. But today she couldn't do that. She had meetings, with people. People that she couldn't ignore. Meetings that she couldn't cancel. Mondays sucked. As Rory ambled through her daily routine, she realized just how much she missed her own house. Her own bed. Her closet. Her coffeemaker. What she didn't miss, though, was the echoes. No, she didn't miss those at all. Most of all she liked that her house wasn't a long commute to work. At the hotel it was. A very long commute. One that normally had her stuck in traffic for over an hour. And today was no different. She had been stuck in traffic for well over an hour, arriving at her office late for her first meetings with a new reporter. "I know, I know, I'm three quarters past late," she said, bustling past her secretary. "Your first meeting was canceled," Mary Jane blurted out after Rory. "What?!" "I tried to call your cell, but it went right to voice mail. Miss Henry had to rush her daughter to the hospital this morning. He swallowed a cat toy... or something." "A cat toy?" "I'm pretty sure that's what she said." "Gross," Rory said, making a face that made her secretary giggle. "She rescheduled for next week." "Hopefully it's on a day when there aren't three wrecks on the road to get to the office," she said, spinning back around to her office. "Oh! You have a visitor!" Mary Jane shouted after Rory. But it was too late. Rory had already pushed open her door to find her husband sitting at her desk. He looked comfortable, she noted as she stared at him, reclined in her chair, his feet propped on her desk. And yet he was the picture of grace. Logan looked at his watch, tapping it with his finger. "A quarter to ten and she finally arrives!" Rory closed the door behind herself. "I wasn't aware that we had an appointment." "We don't. I've been waiting here since eight-thirty for you. You're an hour late." "I'll refrain from reminding you of the many times I waited for you and you didn't show up when you were expected." "Okay, point taken." Rory threw her purse and her briefcase onto the nearest chair, then pulled off her jacket as she asked, "So what are you doing here?" "I'm on my way to Manhattan to have lunch with my sister." "But you felt compelled to stop by and annoy me first?" she asked, moving toward the coffee pot on the far side of the room. "Well... yes," he said with a smirk. "I wanted to run something by you. And doing it over the phone seemed so impersonal." "Oh? And here I thought impersonal was your new thing." He ignored her jabs. "I was wondering if you'd like to go to dinner." Rory turned around to face him. "With you?" "That was the idea, yes." She turned back around to fumble with the coffee pot. "Well, I, uh... I don't know," she stammered as she concentrated on brewing her coffee, trying hard to ignore the fact that her husband had just asked her out. Stranger things have happened, she chided herself. "This is kind of short notice, Logan," she finally told him. "I mean, I have a life, friends, plans... I can't just...," she went on. "Not tonight, Rory," he interrupted, a bit annoyed that she had just assumed that he was just springing this on her. "Oh, I just thought..." "That I normally plan at the last minute?" "Yeah, but in my defense you do so my assumption was partially correct." "Well, I'm turning over a new leaf." "Are you?" she asked, eying him curiously. She didn't know how to take on this new and improved Logan. It was quite an adjustment from the one that she'd come to despise. "So when did you want to have this dinner?" "Whatever night is good for you." "What about whatever night is good for you? I'm sure you have obligations and whatnot." "My schedule is clear and will remain clear. Whatever night you pick, I'll be free." "How?" "What do you mean how?" "How can you just say that you'll be free? You have work and... you have work." He scoffed. She was making fun of him. "Because that's how it is," he deadpanned. "Oh, really?" "I'm not going to win you back jetting off after a story now am I?" "No... you're not." Logan pushed himself to his feet, making his way across the room toward her. "I wanted to see you before I had lunch with Honor." "How come?" she asked as she began pouring coffee into two mugs. "Funny, I thought I made that pretty clear: I wanted to see you." Rory turned toward him, flashing him a smile. "That's sweet." Rory handed Logan a cup of coffee as she told him, "I'm actually glad you stopped by." "You are?" "Yeah." She nodded her head. "After our last conversation I just figured that you would've contacted before now. Waiting an entire week to make a move is not the typical Logan Huntzberger strategy." "I didn't want to seem too overeager." Logan shrugged. "Plus I was kind of holding out hope that you'd call." "You're the guy. You're supposed to call. That's the gentlemanly thing to do." "Says who?" "Says Lorelai." "Ah." Logan glanced at his watch. "Damn. I have to go," he said, setting his coffee mug down on the coffee cart. "Think about dinner." "I will. And tell Honor I said hi." "Of course." Logan wanted to hug her, kiss her, something, but knew that would only make their situation all the more awkward. So he didn't. He gave her a longing look, then began making his way toward the door. "Hey Logan?" Rory called after him. He turned back around to face her. "Saturday?" Logan nodded his head, smiling. "Saturday sounds great." "Call me during the week and we can discuss it further." "Okay. I'll do that." Logan turned back around to leave. "Oh, and hey?" "Yeah?" "Drive safe." Rory was frantic. She couldn't find her pearl earrings. Logan had given her those pearl earrings as a present after graduation. She loved those earrings and she couldn't find them. And they matched perfect with her cream colored dress! Picking up her cell, she dialed her mother's number, begging for Lorelai to answer with each passing ring. "Helloooo," Lorelai answered. "Mom! Do you have my pearl earrings?" "Well, hello to you, too, dear. How am I? I am fine. Perfect, actually. Oh, the weather, it's great. You know, I think the house needs to be painted again. I noticed that the paint has began chipping and I think that...," Lorelai trailed off when Rory cut her off. "MOTHER!" "What?! Sorry. My, my, aren't we in a mood." "I'm sorry. I just... Logan gave me those earrings and I can't find them and usually when my jewelry goes missing, you have it." "Well, I don't have those particular earrings. You always tell me that I'm not allow to borrow any of your Logan bought jewelry." "I do not." "Yes, you do. I'm always in awe of the pretty and you constantly rebuff any and all bribes I throw at you." "I do not." "You do, too. Sorry honey, but I don't have your earrings." "Dammit," Rory cursed as she threw clothes out of her suitcase in a frantic search to find her earrings. "Why do you need them? Hot date?" "As a matter of fact, yes." "You... you have a date?" Lorelai couldn't believe her ears. Her daughter was dating again. Her divorce wasn't even final! Plus, Lorelai wasn't sure that she was even over Logan. "It's just dinner with a guy I used to know," she said sadly. Lorelai was shell shocked. "Wow, I... I didn't think you were ready to date. Who is he?" "I'm not," she said quickly. She wasn't ready for that particular discussion with her mother. Lorelai would be proud to know that she had agreed to work at her marriage. But until she knew if she had marriage left to work at, she didn't want to tell her mother anything. "And it's not even really a date. It's just dinner with a friend, but I can't really talk right now. I need to find these earrings because I'm already late for meeting him." "Okay. Well... have fun, kid. Call me when you get home." "I will." Rory hung up quickly, throwing her phone onto the bed as she reached the bottom of her suitcase, smiling as she caught site of her earrings, hidden in the corner fabric. "Thank goodness!" she said, swooping them up. Walking to the dresser, she put her earrings in, sighing as she gave herself a once over, then caught the site of the clock in the mirror. "Shit. I'm late!" She grabbed her purse and put on her jacket as she exited the room and headed for the elevator. Rory was collecting her ticket from the valet when Logan pulled up behind her car. "You're late," she said when he had stepped onto the sidewalk beside her. He reeked of cigar smoke, hidden under several sprays of expensive cologne. He'd come straight from a meeting, she noted, disappointed. "Yeah, sorry. But I'm not the only one. You arrived just seconds before me." She smiled at him, despite reservations that had begun to sink in. "I couldn't find my earrings," she spat out. It was as good of an excuse as any. "You nearly stood me up for jewelry?" "Not just any piece of jewelry." Logan quickly recognized the earrings that he'd bought for her for her graduation from Yale. He had spent four hours in a jewelry store with Stephanie agonizing on the right type of gift for her. He wanted something beautiful, but totally Rory. He wanted something classy, but wanted to make sure that she would wear whatever it was he bought her. Stephanie had insisted on the pearls. Diamonds suggested something more, she had told him. So, he'd bought her the pearl earrings and Rory had loved them. She'd worn them on their wedding day as well. "They matched my dress." "So I see," Logan said, looking her up and down. "We, um, we should get inside before they give away our table," he said, offering his arm to her. As they made their way into the restaurant, he whispered, "You look beautiful." "And you smell like my grandfather." Logan stared across the table at his wife. She was nervous, that much was obvious. She had barely said two words since they had arrived at their table. She had sent him a look of disdain when she realized that they were dining at a restaurant where the staff knew him on a first name basis. But she'd made no complaints. Not to him, anyway. She'd followed him to the table and said nothing since, save for a few hmm's as she looked over her menu. "I didn't mean to come straight from a business," he told her as they looked over their menus. "It's fine. I can't say I wasn't expecting it." Logan didn't know what to say, and, apparently neither did she since she once again remained silent. When the waiter approached to take their order, Logan sat back as she gave her order. She surprised him when she ordered a salad. "Salad?" he questioned. "Since when do you eat salad?" She just shrugged, choosing not to answer him. She made no move to order anything else, piquing his curiosity. Logan quickly ordered his meal, turning his attention to Rory once the waiter had left their table. "When we used to go to restaurants like this you used to order shellfish of some kind." "I used to love shellfish, until I found out I was allergic to it." "You're allergic to shellfish?" "Yeah. Paris and I had gone to a restaurant one night and I had an allergic reaction to lobster. She had to rush me to the hospital." "You were hospitalized?" he asked, concern etched in his voice. "Only for two days," she said, taking a sip of her water. "When was this? How come I didn't know? How come you didn't call me?" "Logan, it was a while ago. It's no big deal." "No big deal? You went to the hospital and I didn't get a courtesy call?" "You were off somewhere. I didn't know where you were and I wasn't going to pull you away from whatever story it was you were covering to tell you that I was in the hospital after eating bad fish. I went to the hospital, they gave me a shot and the doctor said no more fish until I wanted to look like Flounder again. End of story. Now, would you please drop it?" "No, I won't drop it!" "Look, there are things that you don't care to share with me even though I deserve a right to know. This is one of the things that you probably had the right to know that I kept from you." "So, this is some form of retribution? I was a lousy husband and you're making me pay for it?" "If you want to look at it that way...," Rory finished as the waiter arrived with the bottle of wine that Logan had ordered. The waiter filled Logan's glass and as he moved to fill in her glass, she stopped him. "No, thank you. I can't drink Merlot." "Allergic to that too?" Logan scoffed. She shook her head. "I've taken a dislike to it." "Fine," Logan said shooing the waiter away with the remainder of the bottle. "You've excluded me out of your life on purpose." "Like you haven't excluded me out of yours? Dammit, Logan you didn't even tell me that you were leaving your father's company. I had to hear it on the news. How do you think that made me feel? Then, to hear that you had been meeting with the president of the rival company? I had to take a step back and wonder who this person was that I married. After that it was one thing after another. You would call me en route to wherever it was that you were covering a story. Never once did you invite me along." "It was business." "Including all those dinners with Francesca Moreno?" "How'd you know about those?" "I just know, okay?" "Nothing was going on between Francesca and I. You have to believe that." "I don't have to believe anything you say, Logan. Because, honestly, I don't anymore." "Then why the hell did you agree to this?" Rory shifted her eyes away from him, not wanting to answer his question. He followed her eyes. "Come on. It's not a hard question. Did you do it just to appease me? To see if there was truly anything left between us? What? Come on. Tell me. I'm dying to know why you came when obviously you can't stand to be in the same room with the man that's a mere stranger to you." Rory shrugged. "I don't know, Logan. I've been asking myself that very same question. I mean, I must've been completely insane to believe that Colin had made a valid point when he said that I should try to work things out with you." "Colin? You talked to Colin about us?" "Yeah, he came to my office to reason with me about the divorce." "This is between us, Rory." "Colin's one of our oldest friends. He wants to see us work things out." "You came here because of Colin?" She shook her head. "No not because of Colin," she said sternly, letting out a deep sigh. This man was so frustrating. "I wanted to see for myself if there was anything left between us. Obviously, there isn't," she said standing up quickly. "I don't know why I agreed to this," she said, making a move to leave. His hand on her forearm gave her pause. "Don't leave yet." "Why should I stay?" "Because we already ordered." "And your point is?" She pulled her arm free from his grasp. "You've left me before in the middle of the meal to dine alone. Now you'll see how it feels." Rory left the table without so much as a backwards glance in Logan's direction, feeling horrible for having left him alone. By the time she'd climbed into her car, she realized that what she'd told him at the table was the truth. It wasn't any worse than the many times that he'd left her alone. Once on the road, she decided not to return to the hotel. Instead, she went home.

It was the fourth night in a row that he'd stayed late at the office. After receiving the divorce papers,  he'd given up all hope that Rory was going to come home of her own free will so he had stopped waiting. He concerned himself with work, as usual. It was all he could do to keep his mind off of his failing marriage.

"Don't you ever go home?"

Logan looked up from his work surprised to find Colin standing in the doorway to his office. "No, actually I don't," Logan said as Colin pushed his way into the office.

Colin's eyes roamed the large room. "Nice digs you got here. An upgrade, I see."

"That's right you haven't been here since my promotion."

"Promotion? So you're a hot shot reporter, now?"

"It certainly helps to have been brought up with newspapers all your life. It gives you a certain advantage over everyone else. Plus putting me out there proves well against the competition."

"I'm sure your father loves that."

Colin took a seat in front of Logan, propping his feet onto the corner of his desk. "Have you talked to him any?"

Logan shook his head. "Not since I left the company."

"What about Rory?"

"As far as I know, no. I know that Rory still talks to Honor every now and then, but my parents? No. She despises them almost as much as they do her. More, I think."

"Rory doesn't despise your parents, Logan."

"She doesn't?" Logan asked, baffled.

Colin shook his head. "She hates them. I'm talking deep-seated hate. Hate with every fiber of her being. Hate like..."

"Okay," Logan said, interrupting Colin's tirade. "I get it. She hates them."

Colin waited a few moments, then asked, "So have you heard from her?"

"Why would I? I'm not expecting her to call me and say that she's changed her mind. It's not going to happen."

"Logan..."

"Colin... don't. I know what you're going to say."

"How do you know what I'm going to say?"

"I know what you were going to say because my conscience has been telling me the same thing for the past few weeks. You were going to say that if I love her I'd fight to win her back. That if I really wanted to save my marriage that I would've... that I would've done something."

"I wasn't going to say that verbatim."

"But something of the like?"

"Pretty much."

"Look, I'm dealing with this my own way and forcing myself on her is not going to help. When she's ready to talk to me, she'll talk to me, until then I'm giving her all the space she needs."

"But if you give her too much space she's going to start thinking that you don't want her, either. Call her. Talk to her. Make her see that even though she's ready to call it quits, that you aren't. You can talk to her at the party."

"Shit," Logan muttered, cursing himself for forgetting his best friend's engagement party. "Colin it totally slipped my mind... I've been so preoccupied lately..."

Colin waved it off. He had suspected that Logan had forgotten, which had spurned his late night visit to Logan's office. "It's okay. You have a lot on your mind."

"Rory and I had talked it over when she'd gotten the invitation a few weeks ago, but now... I don't know if it's such a good idea I go. I think I have a business meeting scheduled for tomorrow night anyway."

"If you can't make it, it's fine. It's probably just as well because I think Stephanie's supposed to goad Rory into showing up. At least knowing that you're not going to be there will make it easier to get Rory to agree to show."

"You're sure it's not a problem?"

Colin waved it off. "Not at all. You know I want you there, but if you can't make it, you can't make it. I'm not gonna cry. Just as long as you don't miss the wedding."

"Yeah, like I would miss THAT."

 

If she didn't hurry she was going to be late, Rory realized, glancing at the clock as she sat down on the bed to put on her shoes. After weeks of ignoring Stephanie's phone calls, she had finally called her friend back, only to be blasted for not RSVP'ing to Stephanie and Colin's engagement party. So to make up for ignoring one of her best friends and forgetting to politely RSVP, she had promised Stephanie that she would be at the party early to keep her company.

But she was already fifteen minutes late. 

Moving to her suitcase, she roamed through for her jewelry pouch, her fingers skimming along the velvet box hidden at the bottom of her bag. Wearily, she opened the box, smiling at the glinting diamonds of her wedding ring. She had taken it off after her phone call with Logan feeling that if she was actually going to go through with the divorce that she should try getting used to not wearing her wedding ring. 

As far as she knew no one knew about her and Logan's marital problems. Most of her friends were still under the impression that she and Logan were still together so to keep up pretenses, she would act like a married woman.

She took a moment to weigh her options, then plucked the ring from it's box, sliding it onto it's rightful finger on her left hand. 

Slamming the box shut, she threw it back into her suitcase, hastily grabbed her purse and keys and was out the door.

 

Finn whistled as he walked into the sparse living room. "She took everything with her?" he asked as Logan made his way down the stairs.

Logan shook his head, clasping his watch around his wrist. "I'm not sure what she did with the furniture. I know she hated it so she could've burned it for all I know."

"Do you know where she is?" 

"Yeah, I do."  

"Well, have you gone to talk to her?" Finn asked, following Logan into the kitchen. 

"She doesn't want to talk to me. She doesn't want to hear anything I have to say," Logan told Finn.

"So make her listen."

"It's not that simple, Finn."

"Why not?"

"Because... it's just... not. A lot's happened between Rory and I... even if we could save our marriage, I'm not sure that we could save our relationship. We're not the same people we were in college."

"Obviously."

"What's that supposed to mean?"

"Nothing."

"No. That had to mean something. Now what was it?"

"Just... the Logan I knew in college went after what he wanted. He wouldn't have cared about extenuating circumstances or divorce papers. If he wanted to save his marriage, then he'd do whatever he could to save it. But you're right--you're not the same Logan you were in college."

"Don't say that with such disappointment, Finn."

"Well, I am disappointed, Logan. You're letting her just get away!"

"What the hell am I supposed to do?! Huh? She moved out. She's living in a goddamn hotel room. She served me with divorce papers. As far as she's concerned this is over! I'd be fighting a losing battle, Finn and I just... I can't."

"You're scared that you'll lose her anyway."

Logan stared blankly at Finn.

"If you don't try you'll lose her, but you're also scared that if you do try she'll reject you and it'd have been a moot point."

"It's all moot now anyway. I lost her. I took her for granted. And now... now she's gone and our marriage is over." Logan glanced down at his watch. "I have to go. You know how to let yourself out," Logan yelled over his shoulder.

"You can't just give up, Logan!"

"Watch me!"

 

"You're late!" Stephanie snapped when she opened the door before Rory had a chance to ring the doorbell.

"I know, I know. Traffic was..."

"Oh, don't you dare blame the traffic. You're always late." As Rory began to object, Stephanie took her by the hand, leading her through the house toward the backyard.

"There's a lot of people here," Rory said as Stephanie dropped her hand as they stepped out into the backyard.

"Most of whom Colin and I can't stand, but what can you do. They're here to celebrate," Stephanie told Rory as she led her to the makeshift bar under an oak tree in the backyard of Colin's parents' house. They each ordered their drink and watched as their bartender prepared their drinks. "This was all Candace's doing. She wanted to throw the party. I don't know why she went to so much trouble. She hates me."

"She does not hate you, Stephanie," Rory cajoled her friend, accepting her drink from the bartender. 

"She does hate me. She's always hated me. I've never been good enough for Colin."

"No one is, I think," Rory said as they watched Colin with his mother. 

Stephanie shrugged her shoulders as her eyes searched the crowd for Colin. Her eyes landed on him from across the yard talking to her mother. "Look at them. They're so chummy. Your mom's not like that with Logan, is she?"

Rory shook her head. "Not at all. I mean, they get along, thankfully, but they've never laughed like that."

"You ever think that maybe that's part of your problem?"

"What problem?"

"Why you're so eager to end this marriage? Because your mother doesn't really bond with Logan?"

"What?!" Rory exclaimed. "That's not true. This has nothing to do with my mother."

Stephanie shrugged. "If you say so," she said as she began to walk away. 

Rory ran after her, spinning her around. "Why'd you say that?"

"It was just an observation. Look. Rory, I've noticed that your mother's opinion of your life means a lot to you. You and her have a strong bond and sometimes I think that you're scared to have a strong relationship with anyone but her."

"You think I'm running from my marriage because I'm afraid of being too close to Logan?"

"Precisely."

"That's the craziest thing I've ever heard, Stephanie!"

"It may be but is it so far from the truth? You hold people at arm's length. You let a few get close, but then you manage to push them away. You may not do it consciously, but you do it."

"I...," Rory stammered. Stephanie was making a point and GOD did she hate it that she was so transparent. She hated that Stephanie was able to see straight through her. There were so many reasons on why she had filed for divorce... she couldn't cite one in particular. There were so many reasons why she thought dissolving her marriage was the right thing to do even though in her heart, she knew it wasn't. But only she knew that. That was something she'd keep her herself for the time being.

When Colin joined them, Rory excused herself, leaving the betrothed by themselves. 

"Okay, what'd you do?" Colin asked Stephanie once Rory was out of earshot.

"What makes you think that I did anything?" Stephanie asked innocently.

"The way Rory just stalked off... she looks like the fun has been drained right out of her. What did you say to her, Stephanie?"

"Nothing that wasn't true."

"Leave it be," Colin said sternly. "You can't push them back together so don't try." He knew his girlfriend and if there was one thing Stephanie hated it was when things were not perfect in her world. If an opportunity arose for her to meddle, she would. It was who she was. After all, Stephanie was partially responsible for Rory and Logan being together at all.

They had broken up during Logan's last semester at Yale. When Logan's problems with his father had gotten to be too overwhelming, he had broken things off with Rory. She concentrated on school and made no move to reconcile with him. It was then that Stephanie stepped in and pushed the two of them back together. 

"Oops, too late," she said, smiling as she raised her hand to wave at their latest guest.

"What are you...," Colin began to ask, turning around to spot Logan. "How did you get them both here?" Colin asked, watching as Logan stopped to talk to Stephanie's sister.

Stephanie put a finger over her lips to silence him. "A girl never tells her secrets of deception, Colin," she told him as she began leading him in Logan's direction. 

 

Rory had been talking to Stephanie's parents and her sister Cindy for the past twenty minutes. Then, as if her night couldn't get any worse, Colin's cousin, Melinda, joined in on the conversation. 

Rory extended goodbyes to Stephanie's parents as they moved on to mingle with their other guests and was taken aback when Melinda asked, "You're married to Logan Huntzberger, right?" When Rory didn't answer right away, Melinda continued. "At least I think that's what Colin said."

"Yes, I'm married to Logan. Why? Do you know him?"

Melinda shook her head. "Oh, no. I've just heard things about him. Most of it is just good old gossip, I'm sure," she said with a shrug. "But I heard someone say that his reputation as a ladies man still prevails."

"Does it?" Rory asked, her voice hitching in her throat. She didn't even want to entertain the thought that that shred of gossip bearing any truth.

Melinda nodded. "He works in an office congregated by women. That doesn't bother you?"

"Not at all."

"So you're not at all worried about competition?" Rory shook her head. "I mean, even now that you and he are divorcing?"

Rory watched as Cindy's eyebrows shot up. "You and Logan are divorcing?"

"I... uh... we...," Rory stammered as Colin sidled up beside her.

"Don't you two have other people to annoy. Whether or not Rory and Logan are divorcing is none of your business," he said pointedly, failing not to notice how they were gawking at Rory's wedding ring. Why his mother had chosen to invite Melinda, he would never know. He hated the majority of his kinfolk, barely even acknowledging his parents as members of his family. 

As Melinda slinked off with Cindy in tow, they heard Melinda whisper, "If I was him, I'd demand the ring back. I'm sure it's probably worth a small fortune."

"It's probably in the pre-nup," Cindy added with a look thrown over her shoulder at Rory and Colin.

"Don't listen to them," Colin said, wrapping a reassuring arm around her shoulders.

Rory leaned into him, resting her head on his shoulder. "Does everyone know?"

"Word travels fast, Rory. This is Hartford, you know where anything concerning the Huntzberger's is everyone's business. At least they make it their business."

"I wanted to keep it quiet... I wanted this to be just between Logan and I... and now... God, he's going to think I'm going around bragging to everyone that we're getting a divorce. He's going to hate me."

"No he's not."

Rory spun around quickly, her knees weakening at the sight of Logan standing behind her. Her eyes never left his as she heard Colin say, "I'll leave you two alone to talk."

 

It took Rory a few moments to find her voice, finally able to spit out a chocked, "Hi."

Logan smiled at her in kind. "From the look on your face, I guess you didn't know that I was here either."

Rory shook her head. "Stephanie said that you weren't coming. I'm just surprised to see you."

"I wasn't going to come. I didn't want to face everyone and the onslaught of questions regarding the two of us, and I guess a part of me didn't want to face you either, but I knew that I should be here."

"I agree. Colin and Stephanie are your oldest friends. I thought it would've been rude for you to not celebrate with them." She looked over her shoulder where Stephanie, Colin and Finn were watching them. 

"I came for you, too," he spat out truthfully.

"Pardon me?" 

"I wanted to see you."

At his sentiment, Rory didn't know what to do or say so she did the only thing that sprang to mind. She turned around to leave. Logan's hand caught her wrist, willing her around to face him.

"Look at me, Ace."

She was reluctant to look at him at first, but finally lifted her eyes to meet his, hating what she saw--desperation.

"I just want to talk to you."

Rory's eyes dropped to her waist, realizing that he was holding her hand. The moment they both noticed what had transpired within a few moments, they pulled their hands away.

She folded her arms across her chest. "I don't know, Logan. I don't think...," she began to object.

"Five minutes. That's all I ask."

"Five minutes."

 

When Colin and Finn had carted Logan away, Rory took that as her chance to lash out at Stephanie for the obvious setup. "You're devious!" Rory shouted at Stephanie, pulling her away from her flirting match with the bartender.

"Oh, I guess you saw Logan."

"Yes I saw Logan! Did you think I wouldn't?"

Stephanie let out a deep sigh. "Look, Rory. I'm looking out for you. I don't want you to regret this," she said. "And you will," she added when Rory scoffed. "Things may not have turned out like you expected, but honestly what did you expect marrying a newspaper tycoon. It's who Logan is. It's who he's always been. He's been bred for it and you knew that even before you were married. I'm not saying to forgive him for what he's done because most of the blame lies with him, but you're not innocent here yourself. You could've told him what you were planning to do before you did it. But you didn't. You didn't give him the chance to try to mend fences. You closed the door on him before he could even unlock it." Stephanie gulped down the remaining contents of her martini. "And, FYI, I didn't invite him as a subplot to get the two of you together. You were invited before your separation. I had it on good authority that he wasn't coming, but obviously he changed his mind."

"Obviously," Rory said, watching Logan with Colin and Finn. The three best friends were engaged in a private conversation, laughing and joking much like they did in college.

"Think about what you're doing putting him back on the market," Stephanie whispered in her ear before walking away. 

Rory made her way to the bar for another drink. As she sat down and began to sip on her second martini, she watched as Melinda joined Colin, Finn and Logan. She watched the easy way that Melinda flirted with Logan to only have him reject her by showing her his wedding ring. A chill ran down her spine when Logan turned in her direction to point her out to Melinda, sending her a half-hearted smile after Melinda had retreated in a huff.

Rory held Logan's gaze for a moment, then broke it to look down at her own wedding ring. 

Pushing off her barstool, she made her way toward the house. She bounded upstairs, heading for the bathroom, but changed her direction, finding her way into Colin's old bedroom. She closed the door behind herself, needing a few moments to collect herself. She made her way to the bed to sit down, dropping her head into her hands. 

It was supposed to be cut and dry. Leave. Divorce. The End. But it wasn't turning out to be as simple as she had hoped. The walls around her had been breaking since Logan's phone call a few days before. To hear his voice, to hear him remind her of how much he loved her was enough to make her crack and begin to rethink her decision. It wasn't easy letting go and she wasn't even all that positive that she was ready to let go even though she strongly backed her claim to her friends and her family.

She wanted to believe that if she gave him a chance that he would change. She wanted him to.  But she didn't want to risk being put into the exact situation six months from now. She couldn't risk it. She couldn't risk hurting again.

She heard the door creak open a few moments later. She let out a deep resonating sigh before she said, "You know if you want to sneak up on me, you should start wearing a different cologne." She turned to look at him, asking, "What are you doing in here, Logan?"

"I thought we could talk since we were interrupted earlier."

"Here? Now?"

"It seems as good a time as any."

"You want to hash this out now? Can't it wait?"

Logan shook his head. "No, it can't. You're not getting out of here until you talk to me," he said sternly. 

"What's there to talk about, Logan?"

"Everything, Rory," he said, pushing himself away from the door. He moved toward the bed, sitting down beside her, leaving a reasonable amount of space between. 

"Logan I just think... if we talk about this you're going to have false hope. I don't want to give you hope that this could work. I've made up my mind."

"So you've completely closed the door? No matter what I do... no matter what I say, this is it?"

She nodded her head slowly. "You closed the door when you shut me out. After you left your father's company you worked harder to prove to him that you could make it without him." Rising to her feet, she told him, "But you only proved that you could make it without me."

"Rory..."

"Logan... I can't," she told him, taken off-guard when he grabbed her wrist. It had always been his way to get her attention. Every time they argued, she would do her best to shut him out, ignore him, but he would always grab her wrist, forcing her to look at him, forcing her to feel how powerful their connection was just by the touch of his hand. 

Like now. Pulsating stronger than ever. 

His eyes moved to her hand, his thumb brushing over her diamond ring. "You're wearing your wedding ring," he noted, hopeful.

"So? I like it."

"That's the only reason?"

"What other reason would there be?"

Logan shrugged. "I don't know... I thought... maybe..."

"See? This is what I didn't want. This means nothing, Logan," she said, slipping the ring off. "Our marriage is dead and if you need clarity, then here," she said, holding her wedding ring out to him.

"What are you doing? I don't want it."

"Take it."

"It's yours. I don't want the damn thing."

Rory grabbed Logan's hand, placing the ring into his palm. She balled up his fist as she told him, "There. We're finished. Are we all clear?"

"Crystal," he said through gritted teeth.

Rory left Logan alone in the room, passing Colin in the hallway. Colin peered into his old room, finding Logan sitting on his bed, staring at his hands. "What happened?"

"It's over. I guess I finally have to accept it."

Colin noticed what Logan was staring at it. "Is that...?"

"Rory's wedding ring? It sure is. She wanted to make things crystal clear to me that we are over."

"So you're just giving up?"

Logan rose from the bed, shaking his head. "Of course not. If she thinks she's getting rid of me that easily she's sadly mistaken."

Logan sat at his desk, watching as his co-workers bustled out of their offices, glad to be calling it a day before dusk. It was Friday so everyone was headed home to spend the long holiday weekend with their families. 

Fridays were a reminder of the start of a weekend normally filled with relaxation and free time. They were also a constant reminder of the one thing that he didn't have that his co-workers did: a family to go home to. 

Reclining back in his chair, Logan took a moment to run his hands across his face. He winced realizing that he hadn't shaved in days. Nearly a week, actually. He hadn't felt the need to. When at home he drowned himself in Scotch and the deafening silence of the house. At work he buried himself with his usual tasks. Anything to keep his mind off of Rory and the fact that she had yet to make any contact at all.

Pushing out of his desk chair, he made his way over to the window. 

He watched as the sun made it's descent from the sky, exploding the sky in a rainbow of colors. Rory loved sunsets. She loved sunrises, too. He wondered if she still did... 

Had things between the two of them really reached the breaking point? Where things between them so bad that he had to wonder if things that he had once loved and admired about her were no longer part of who she was?

He'd picked up the phone to call her numerous times, but always slammed it down. He never knew what to say. He never knew how to convey his feelings. Maybe that was the problem. He had never learned how to talk to her, to trust her. Perhaps that was why he had spent so much energy keeping her out. 

Perhaps.

Settling back into his chair, Logan stared at the empty computer screen before him, groaning. The shrill sound of his ringing phone, pierced the silence. "Hello?"

"It's Friday and you're still working?"

Logan smiled, leaning back in his chair. "Colin? Man, it seems like forever since we've spoken."

"Yeah, it has been forever. So, did you get the invitation?"

"Invitation? For what?"

"For the engagement party?"

"Oh. Right. The engagement party. Yeah. We got it."

"You didn't RSVP. I hope you and Rory can come."

"Yeah... we'll see."

"So speaking of the missus, how is she? I know that she's been avoiding Stephanie's phone calls. Finn's too. Everything okay?"

"I'm sure they are."

"What, you don't know?"

"Actually, I don't.

"Is there something I should know?" Colin asked, panicked.

"She, uh... she left."

"Like... left?"

"Yeah. I came home from work one day and she was gone. She'd cleared out the living room and packed our marriage away into a box."

"I'm sorry, Logan. I didn't know."

"It's okay. No one did. It's not something you want publicized, you know."

"I'm sure. Look if you ever need to talk..."

"Thanks for the offer, but it's not necessary. We'll work it out." 

"Anyway, I was calling to invite you out for drinks with me and Finn."

"I don't know... I have tons of work I should probably do." 

"Just a few hours. It'll take your mind off of everything." 

"Drinks sounds great. Where?"

"Murphy's Pub downtown. Finn and I will be there. Just find us."

"I'll meet you there in a half-hour."

As Logan began packing papers into his briefcase, he chanced a look up as a young blonde woman approached his door. "Mr. Huntzberger?"

Smiling cordially, he asked, "Yes? May I help you?"

She walked toward him, handing him a clipboard. "I need you to sign," she told him, instructing to a blank line at the bottom of the page.

"What's this?" Logan asked as scribbled his signature. 

The woman shrugged. "I do not know, sir," she said as she handed him a long yellow envelope. "I'm just the messenger. Have a nice weekend."

"Yeah, you, too," he said, watching as the woman exited his office. Curious, Logan tore open the envelope. He pulled out the papers from inside, his eyes widening as he skimmed them. "You have got to be kidding me," he muttered to himself.

Logan took a moment to thumb through the papers before he picked up his phone, taking a deep breath before he began to dial.



Rory was sitting out on the balcony of her hotel room, her phone lying in her lap as she waited for the inevitable phone call. When it vibrated, she looked down and wasn't surprised to see Logan's name on the display.

Clearing her throat, she answered the phone with a choked, "Hello?"

"Divorce papers!," Logan shouted. "You served me with divorce papers?" He was angry. That much was obvious. She had prepared for him being angry. 

"Logan..."

"Don't even try to make me calm down, Rory! First you leave without telling me, then you file for divorce? We didn't get to talk this over."

"What good would that have done? We'd be exactly where we are now."

"I get it. You're upset. But this? Tell me that you aren't serious about this."

"I am."

"Come home. We can talk about this," he pleaded with her. He hated having to resort to begging, but if it was a last resort, he'd certainly take it.

"Home? Home is in Stars Hollow, Logan. My grandparents house is more homey than that castle that I've been living in for the past three years. I can't sustain this marriage by myself. I can't do this alone. I won't do this alone."

"I'm not asking you to. I'm asking you to give me a chance to make it better."

"You can't make it better. You've spent the last three years making it worse and frankly Logan I think it's time we both face it. This isn't going to work. You and me--we're not going to work." She pleaded with him, "Just... just sign the papers."

"No, I'm not signing the papers," he said sternly. 

"If you love me, you'd sign them."

"It's because I love you I'm refusing to sign them. We can work this out, Rory. I know we can. You can't be willing to throw away a six year relationship because..."

"Because what, Logan? I'd love for you to be able to tell me why it was I left."

"That's just it. I have no idea why you left. You never said anything. If you'd just told me..."

"Told you? When was I supposed to tell you? When you were jetting off to Paris or London? When you were sleeping at the office instead of coming home? When you decided that work was more important than me?"

"How could you say that?" He asked, genuinely hurt by her accusation. "Rory, you're the most important thing in my life. Work is definitely not more important than you."

"It certainly feels that way, Logan."

"I can't help the way you feel, even if it is unfounded. You can't be questioning how much I love you. You know I love you."

"Do I? You haven't... how could I when... I married you because I love you, because I wanted to spend my life with you. You married me because you needed an arm piece."

"Seriously you can't honestly believe that?"

He waited for a response, but when he received none, he sighed knowing that he didn't need one. Her silence was all the answer he needed. He knew that he was fighting a losing battle anyway. She'd made up her mind and she wasn't about to let him change it. "What do you want me to do?"

"I want you to sign the papers."

"I won't do that."

"Logan, please."

"You can ask me to do anything but that. You may have made up your mind that we're not worth fighting for, but that doesn't mean that I have. I'm not giving up on us, Rory."

"There's nothing you can do to make this right. It's over, Logan. I've faced it. It's time that you face it," she said, her voice cracking before she hung up the phone.

Logan closed his eyes, letting the phone slip from his grasp. He debated calling her back, but she would only ignore his call. Instead, he collected himself and headed downtown to meet Colin and Finn.



At the pub, Colin and Finn were circled around a table laden with beer bottles and shot glasses. Obviously they'd been at this a while, Logan mused as he joined them, greeting them with a forced smile, regretting having shown up at all seeing that his mood didn't mirror theirs.

Colin was the first to realize that something was remiss. "Everything okay, buddy?" he asked, sensing Logan's foul mood.

Logan shook his head as he stared at the table in front of him, lifting it only to say, "No, everything's not okay." 

He signaled to the waitress, ordering a round of shots, then five extra shots. It was then that Colin and Finn exchanged a look, realizing that something was definitely off-kilter.

When the waitress returned with their shots, Logan lifted his glass. "A toast, gentlemen."

Colin and Finn lifted their glasses as well, Colin asking, "What are we toasting to?"

"Here's to friendship, good booze... and the demise of my marriage. Cheers!" Logan clinked his glass with Colin's and Finn's, then knocked back his shot as his friends stared at him dumbfounded.

They didn't know what to say and he was grateful that they remained silent as he drowned himself in his drink of choice for the night. For some reason he found that tequila was solace. It helped dull the pain. For a little while at least. Sure, it wasn't what he was accustomed to, and he'd sure as hell regret it tomorrow, but for tonight he didn't give a damn.

His world as he knew it was slipping away and try as he might, he couldn't stop it. 

But he could prolong the knowledge of it for a few hours and he proceeded to do just that as he beckoned to the waitress for a fresh round of drinks.

When things begin to slip away, what to you do? You return to the beginning and start anew. She could hear the birds chirping before she even heard the alarm buzzing from her beside table. She groaned against the intrusion of the bright Monday morning sun in her still sleep hazed eyes as she reached over to turn off her alarm. She knew that she was alone in bed before she even turned her head. It wasn't a new occurrence, waking up alone, going to bed alone. She spent the majority of her days alone, not including spending time with her friends and her family. She and Logan had been married almost three years to the day. He'd promised her when he'd took a job with an opposing company of his father's that he'd make time for her. He had promised her that he would not turn into his father. He'd broken those promises. She barely recognized the man that shared her home. It was Logan's face, his eyes, his voice, but it wasn't him, something that shook her to the core. She longed for the prankster, the guy that took her to plays and fell asleep. The one that had made her go on a scavenger hunt before he proposed. Forcing herself out of bed, she padded on bare feet to the bathroom. She flipped on the bathroom light, leaning against the doorjamb wishing for an article of clothing that belonged to him, his toothbrush on the bathroom counter, something that was his that gave her a signal that he at least came home. Title: The Aftermath of a Kiss Fandom: Veronica Mars Rating: PG Genre: Episode Related, Angst Characters: Veronica Mars, Logan Echolls Spoilers: "Weapons of Class Destruction" Disclaimer: I claim ownership to nothing. Summary: Logan's POV after his and Veronica's first kiss. Her eyes are questioning now.

What prompted you to kiss me? What are your intentions?

I'm not sure what my intentions are. I'm not even sure if I have any intentions at this point.

It had building between us the past few weeks. This want, this need to be near her.

And the need to protect her...

Six months ago... three months ago I had never thought that I would be risking my friendship with Duncan for Veronica. I never thought that I would be looking at Veronica as anything more than an enemy.

But now...

I can't fight this feeling.

I'm not even quite sure what this feeling is.

I just know that I need to talk to her, but I can't when she keeps looking at me like that.

I wait a week. It's a sufficient amount of time.

She's alone in the newspaper room doing research. I close the door behind me to afford us a little bit of privacy. She turns around when she hears the click of the door.

"Logan... hey," she greets me with a fake smile.

"We should probably talk."

She shuts down her computer, turning in her chair to face me. "Yeah... we probably should." Before I can get one word out, she says, "You kissed me."

Apparently a kiss from me is a death wish. Ah, the romance of it all.

"Yeah, I did."

"Why'd you do that?"

"You kissed me first."

"But I kissed you on the cheek, Logan. As a thank you for coming to my rescue."

I play with the zipper on my jacket as she speaks. "What do you want me to say, Veronica? I'm sorry? Because I'm not." She's taken aback by my forwardness. "I wanted to kiss you. I've wanted to kiss you for... a long time. I've thought about it... but the moment was never right and then the other day... the opportunity presented itself so I threw caution to the wind and seized the moment."

She pushes herself to her feet and I realize that we're just inches apart. "What now?"

She's looking at me with those big eyes of hers so I seize the moment again.

My arm circles her waist, pulling her against me as my lips attack hers. She whimpers softly, but opens her mouth allowing my tongue entrance.

She feels and tastes just like I had imagined. Soft and sweet.

After a few moments, she breaks away. "What are we doing?"

"Well, um...," I start to say, but I tamp down the urge to be a smartass.

"We can't do this, Logan. You're you and I'm me and we can't... we can't," she says defiantly.

"Veronica, it was only a kiss."

"It was two kisses, Logan. No wonder you failed freshman algebra."

I pull her back to me, surprised that she lets me. She fingers the lapels on my jacket as she says, "Things are going to change, Logan." She lifts her eyes to meet. "Nothing is going to be the same."

"I'm aware of that. I was actually counting on it."

"Be serious, Logan. I've already been toyed with once this year."

"I assure you, Veronica, I'm not toying with you. I wouldn't do that." I gently tucked her hair behind her ears. "Not to you."

She steps forward, looping her arms around my neck. Her kiss is soft and her lips barely touch mine. "I'm late," she says.

I watch as she turns to grab her backpack. "Walk to you to your car?"

"Sure," she says with a smile. "Who said Logan Echolls wasn't chivalrous."

"Hey, I do have a reputation to withhold. Don't go on spreading that around school."

"I can see the headline for the paper: LOGAN ECHOLLS - GENTLEMAN?"

I can't remember the last time I laughed so freely.

But it felt good.

We make our way outside to her car in silence. She unlocks it and I pull open the door for her. "Thank you," she says, kissing my cheek before she climbs in behind the steering wheel.

"So, tomorrow's Friday," I say casually.

"Uh huh... usually it is the day that comes after Thursday."

I roll my eyes before saying, "Maybe we could do something."

In true Veronica fashion, she says, "Maybe," as she starts her car.

I watch as she pulls out of the school parking lot still watching her car as my phone vibrates from my pocket. I answer it quickly. "Logan."

"So, what's your definition of 'something'?"

Title: State of Attraction Characters/Relationships: Rory/Logan Summary: POV. Colin is in a state of disarray and it's all because of Rory. Disclaimer: I don't own 'em.

Attraction.

She was around constantly. Everywhere we were, there she was. At first it was attraction purely based on the fact that she was beautiful. She was... really, really beautiful. I could see what Logan saw in her.

"How do you do it?"

"Do what?"

"Logan?"

"He has his moments."

"I'm not the heartless bastard that you think I am."

"Oh, I don't think...," she was too quick to defend.

I nod my head slowly. "Of course you do, Rory. A lot of people do and really it's okay. I know how I act and how I treat people. I'm not proud of it all of the time, but that's how it is. Blame it on bad breeding, if you will."

"Colin, you're not that bad."

I laugh. "You're sweet."

"I just wanted to make sure that you were okay. You stormed out of the dorm pretty quick."

She sighs. "It's just... it's weird getting readjusted. After the summer apart."

I don't know what urges me to do it, but my hand makes it way to her leg and I pat it lightly. "If it's any consolation, Rory. He thought about you constantly. Talked about you incessantly."

She smiles and my heart flutters. "Thank you, Colin. You're a good friend. Logan is lucky to have you."

I stand up as Logan walks into the library, his eyes falling upon her. "I think we should talk," he tells her.

She nods, then stands. She looks at me, smiles, then takes Logan's outstretched hand and they head for the door.

At the door, she pauses, casting a look in my direction. Her blue eyes are dancing as she flashes a smile directed at me.

As Logan pulls her through the door, she pulls a piece of my heart with her.

And it's official.

I'm in trouble.

And I'm really okay with that.<
